\n\n\n\n\n\n\n \n
\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 8739728027:\n\n\n\n\n\nGAAD 2014 Interview with Keith Bundy\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

Thank you for your interest in the GAAD 2014 Interview with Keith Bundy.

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

Listen to or download the audio file here. (MP3, 33.6Mb)

\n

Download the transcript here. (Microsoft® Word, 161Kb)

\n

 

\n

GAAD 2014 Interview with Keith Bundy - April 16, 2014 (Transcript)

\n

KEVIN: Hi folks, this is Kevin Rydberg from Siteimprove and in recognition of Global Accessibility Awareness Day 2014, we are going to go ahead and have a brief conversation with our friend Keith Bundy to talk about some of the different daily challenges he faces as a person with a disability.

\n

What is Global Accessibility Awareness Day? Well it’s a community driven effort whose goal is to dedicate one day to raising the profile and introducing the topic of digital accessibility, which would be website software, mobile apps, assistive devices, etc., and also people with different disabilities, we want to introduce it to the broadest audience possible.

\n

So in that vein we’re going to go and get started and I’d like introduce you to my friend Keith Bundy. Keith, can you give us a little information about yourself?

\n

KEITH: Well hello folks, it's great to be on the call with Kevin. I am or I'm totally blind; I was born totally blind and the currently serve as the assistant Dean for Student Development at Dakota State University and as the pastor of First Baptist Church in Madison, [SD].

\n

I also do a few consulting jobs with assistive technology whenever the opportunity presents itself, because one thing that I have seen developed over my lifetime, is the improvement in accessibility. And of course we still got a ways to go but when you look back to where we were, say 25 years ago when I first came to South Dakota, and where we are today there's no contest. It is extremely very much improved. We’ve still got a ways to go but accessible is been a part of my life for years and so I like to work in that element of every opportunity I get.

\n

And if anybody is interested in my personal life, I have a wife whose name really is Peg Bundy; she's nothing like the gal from Married With Children, but that is her name and I have four boys and all of those folks can see so I'm the only blind person in our family; my blindness was not hereditary.

\n

KEVIN: Keith, can you go ahead and give us, kind of a list of some of the adaptive technology did you use; some of the devices that you use on a daily basis?

\n

KEITH: Sure. Probably the most used piece of assistive technology that I have is the JAWS for Windows as a screen reader. I also know how to use screen readers called Window Eyes and NVDA, Non-Visual Desktop Access, and System Access but JAWS is probably the screen reader that I use the most. I have a umm, JAWS has built-in voice synthesizers using the computer soundcard, which is what it does for me.

\n

I also use a braille display. I prefer to use a Brailliant 32-cell display that I have that that helps JAWS not only speak what's on the screen but put it in braille, so that I can access it in that way. I can read it in braille and type in braille; it does automatic translations so that the person I’m sending an email to or preparing a document for will not even realize that was done in braille.

\n

I also have a braille 1012 which is a very small braille display that is very useful when you’re just kind of on the fly and looking for access with a mobile platform in particular. I use the iPhone with a piece of assistive technology called Voiceover. Interestingly enough Apple was the first company to have accessibility out of the box with its devices. It began I want to say with the Tiger version of their OS in Mac; I could be incorrect on that it may have been an earlier version but I think it started with Tiger.

\n

Voiceover comes on all Mac computers and it's been on the iPhone and iPod and iPad ever since iOS4 came out. And so I use the iPhone regularly both for work and personal use. Again I use voice over and braille displays that I use also will interface with the iPhone very nicely; so for me for example if I go to meetings, instead of taking the entire computer system often I'll just take the iPhone and the braille display and be able to take notes and access information that way. When I do my sermons on Sunday mornings, I will either have my netbook or just the iPhone with the sermon notes and then just be able to access it from the braille display right there and it is become very convenient.

\n

One other piece of assistive tech that I use frequently is called Kurzweil 1000. It's an OCR system, which stands for optical character recognition, and it is designed specifically for people who are blind or visually impaired. It basically ignores images and puts printed text into a very accessible format on the computer. Interestingly enough with the iOS continually improving, they're coming out was pretty good scanning devices for the iPhone that are like the fraction of the cost for Kurzweil. So I also have a program called PRIZMO, that's P-R-I-Z-M-O, on my iPhone and I do some scanning and reading that program as well.

\n

KEVIN: Wow; that's pretty amazing. So with accessibility, the access improving as much as it has, do you think that that is attributed to the devices or you think it attributed to improvement in how websites are built in accessible coding practices?

\n

KEITH: Both. It is a tribute to devices obviously because without the devices continually improving, accessibility would obviously be far a more limited. But I think there's also big improvement because people are beginning to realize that accessibility is a benefit and not just something they ought to do. It's been said in one piece of information that I read that that in the very near future over 20% of the population will need some form of accessibility. That’s not only due to the disabilities that may be people were born with, or developed in life, but as the baby boomers get more toward that retirement age and start developing more vision issues they can benefit from accessibility.

\n

So what we're discovering is the companies that design their websites with accessibility in mind are able to reach that population while other companies who don't are going to end up losing that market share in the future. So the fact that more people are aware of what accessibility will do and are learning the coding that will make things extremely accessible is definitely a great help.

\n

Poorly done websites are still not very accessible sometimes. I'm thinking of one right now in our area that I'm working with to improve accessibility, it’s a newspaper in the area and it took me, and I would consider myself an advanced user jaws—I’ve been using JAWS for Windows for 17 years, taught people pretty much for 17 years on it, and so I pretty much no program inside and out, and it took me—I don’t know—weeks to figure out how to make the site even… workable with a screen reader. Still not perfect, but at least I've got it where I can access it. So yeah I think there's a lot of room to go in the coding, but I think other people coding in seeing the need for accessibility has been a major factor in improving things.

\n

KEVIN: Okay, you talked briefly about your iPhone a moment ago. Let’s go ahead and dig into that a little bit more and talk more about mobile devices. You actually consider your mobile device assistive technology not just a cell phone or a smart phone, correct?

\n

Keith: You bet. You bet. While it will do the things a cell phone will do, I use it for well, pretty much all of my reading outside the office. I use the iPhone4. I have a couple programs on there, well, probably four programs including Amazon's Kindle app and their native iBooks app which let me read materials such as books, magazines on there; and so most of my reading is done on the iPhone with the braille display or with speech.

\n

I have not ordered a braille book from the Library of Congress; they have a braille reading program available. I haven’t ordered the book for probably well…at least since the iPhone came out, and I think even before that because I had another piece of a braille note taker called Braille Note that would also read books in braille. So I don't even use the braille service anymore. In addition you know when oftentimes when I'm home I will answer my work email on the iPhone just because it saved me from getting out the computer and I can answer it just a lot easier on the iPhone.

\n

I use it to provide navigation information when my family and I travel or if I'm walking in an area not familiar with. There are several navigation programs, and so in the best of smartphone, you know, the iPhone does a lot of things for me. There is even a program out there—there’s a couple programs, but I wanna talk about one in particular called TapTapSee, and it is a program that if you have an iPhone, and it is now moved into the Android market as well, you can take a picture of something and it will use a combination of crowdsourcing and a database to tell you what that picture is.

\n

You might have to take the picture a few times, for example when I bought my laundry, my washer and dryer, we were not even thinking accessibility. And so we got it home found out that the dryer and the washer, the settings are totally inaccessible. You can't—they’re all-digital—you can't set them at all. Well I found out that with this program called TapTapSee, I can point my smart phone at this, at the knob, the dial and I could take a picture. It might take a couple of attempts, one time it took four attempts, but I'll eventually get a picture back stating where it’s set. You know whether it sat on normal or delicate or whatever and then I can know what it’s set on approximately, how to move it to get it set properly. And then I’ll send another picture to make sure it's set correctly.

\n

There's another program that I think is kind of losing his popularity but it's called BizWiz — that’s B-I-Z-W-I-Z—and they actually have people you can ask them specific questions so if you send a picture of them you can just say literally what is this dryer’s dial set on? What control is set on? And they’ll answer you back.

\n

They’ll either tell you the picture’s not good enough. Believe me as a totally blind person learning to take pictures, it is been experience because having never seen before, I've had a lot of learning to do. But the cool thing is I'm able to do that fairly well now. In fact on a little side note, if you were to go to my Facebook page and see pictures of my grandson, most of those I took myself.

\n

The iPhone even has a future where if you point the camera will tell you if it's focused, how many faces are in view, whether it's in the center of the camera or not, and a blind person is able to take pictures as well. So as you can see, the iPhone is a whole lot more than what most people use a smartphone for in my case.

\n

KEVIN: That’s pretty amazing! You touched on your home life a little bit. Let’s go ahead and switch gears for a moment and ask you a couple questions that are to be more about your day-to-day activities; and a lot of them are kind of mobility related. For example, how do you get to work, Keith?

\n

KEITH: Well I have a guide dog. I have learned orientation mobility skills at an early age and I am also user of white cane but I found out a few years ago the guide dog help me to move a little faster and so I got a guide dog, my first one in 1992. I am currently with my third one. So we just walked to work. I happen to be a good location where, maybe only three-quarters-of-a-mile from the office. There are sidewalks the entire way. I obviously had to teach the dog to route, but now he's pretty much in autopilot. He knows exactly where we’re going. So I walk with him on a daily basis to the office. And then we can walk home as well or if we’re feeling a little on the lazy side or whatever, or it’s raining or something, my wife doesn't mind come to pick us up. But the good news is, or the important thing is we could walk both ways if we desire to, and sometimes we do.

\n

KEVIN: Now you stated her little bit ago something about navigation. Did you say that you were a navigator for the family?

\n

KEITH: I am! When we go on trips I have, well, prior to GPS technology I would memorize maps and would just tell my family the roads we needed to take. We’ve taken trips where my wife is never open the atlas once we got on the road because of my, you know, the ability that God has given me to help be a navigator. The other thing that I do now with GPS is I can just plug in the location into Google Maps or Navigon or something along those lines that will tell us where to go, where the turns are, and so it works very well. Also, when I was navigating without Google Maps, I do remember there was a time or two I got my family lost, just like anybody else, and I still remember the day we went over the Mississippi River three times on the two-lane bridge and my wife was not impressed at that moment with my navigational abilities. But for the most part I do all of our navigating when we travel. Love it!

\n

KEVIN: So you enjoy traveling. Now let's go ahead and talk airplane travel for a moment. I’m going to give you a three-part question here. First of all, I'm assuming that you travel by airplane, and if so, how does it work with bringing your guide dog on the plane? And also is it fairly easy to get around airports by yourself or is it difficult to get around?

\n

KEITH: Good questions. I do travel by plane. I fly several times a year for the university, for speaking engagements and workshops that I'm involved in, and Mercury gets to go right with me on the on the plane. He is trained how to handle situations of flying, and he just basically fits so between my feet under the seat and we can travel like that. What they will do if the flights not real busy, not totally full, they’ll try to give us two seats so that we can stretch out a little bit but we have traveled when that hasn't been able to happen and it's really no problem. He just walks with me on the plane, knows how to get under the seat and away we go. Most people don't even notice he’s there until they, till they see him on their way out of the plane. I’ve often had people comment as they’ll walk by and see him looking up at them and say, “Oh man, I didn’t know there was a dog on the plane.” So it’s absolutely no problem.

\n

Airports are a little interesting. Now I am in the process of exploring this a little more. There are a lot of people who are blind who navigate airports by themselves. I'm getting ready to learn how to do that because often I will just ask for a “Meet and Assist”. Pretty much every time I fly, unless I’m with someone, and that Meet and Assist will meet me at the gate and make sure I get to the next gate. But occasionally you’ll have a real close call with something like that; like the last time I flew I was in a conference in Louisville, had to fly through Atlanta to get home, had an hour layover and of course the Meet and Assist was not on time and so we walked in the gate area just of their plane was boarding and I don't like cut that close.

\n

So there's some things on the web that talk about traveling independently in airports so I’m going to see what I can learn and just see if we can get to that point. I will probably try Minneapolis first because I probably flown into and out of that airport more than any other one, and I Kind of got the lay of land there I think, but usually I use a Meet and Assist at this time.

\n

KEVIN: When you are go to a new location, someplace you haven't been before—this is a little is travel-related but it's also kind of technology related—what is it like, do you try to get on a wireless network? Do you rely on 4G? Tell me a little bit about your experiences about getting to new places and getting, you know, keeping your technology connected and hooked in.

\n

KEITH: You bet. Well what I will usually try to do once I’m at a hotel or conference center is log on to their wireless network with all of my devices. Fortunately though I have a fairly high data plan; a fairly good amount of data and so I will also use 4G. In fact usually if I'm a shuttle say from an airport to hotel, I will pull up a GPS program just to help me orient to the area, to let me know what were passing by what roads were taking that kind of thing. But usually when I can access the wireless networks, I will usually have asked someone for the password because obviously when you're blind you can't see the little things in the room that let you know the password, so you just have to ask someone. But I've never run into a problem with that and I'll was try to access the wireless network as soon as possible because I use the technology extensively when I'm visiting someplace.

\n

KEVIN: Interesting. So that would be a whole ‘nother session that we could do just talking about travel and your day-to-day activities and let's get back on track on the tech here for just a couple more minutes and then I’ll let you go, but let's talk for a few minutes about accessible documents. How many times a day do you encounter a Word file, Excel file, a PDF document that you know, that you need to use and that you may have issues with accessibility?

\n

KEITH: Fortunately not as often as I used to. The biggest issue that I face today is PDF documents that people scan where they don't do any conversion. Fortunately for me, Kurzweil1000 has a system where you can just open the PDF document and Kurzweil scans the document and it converts it to very readable format, pretty much immediately and that I can save it in whatever format I choose. Word documents most people do pretty good right now. Occasionally people will give me screenshots. Those are very tough to use sometimes they can be gotten with Kurzweil and a few other piece of technology called Open Book. Sometimes they can't yet have someone read them to you. Screenshots are not the blind person’s friend—screen capture.

\n

Excel, I haven’t had too many issues with whatsoever at this point. Most Excel documents are pretty good. Word documents, if they’re long, it's really appreciated if the person writing the document will use stuff such as headings, styles, things like that because with the screen reader we can navigate to different parts of the document with what are called navigation quick keys that can maybe enable you to navigate by heading, or by table, or by certain styles and the and that's very very helpful.

\n

The the one thing that but I would want to mention about the webpages while we’re at it, I'm more likely to run across a webpage that's not very accessible And one simple thing that people can do to make webpages accessible without a whole lot of coding, you know, in my mind there’s two levels of accessibility—legal accessibility and comfortable accessibility.

\n

Some pages are legally accessible but not very convenient to use and I’ll avoid them if possible. Other pages are very comfortable to use and that you can make a page really comfortable for people who have accessibility by using cascading style sheets, making sure that you use headings, making sure that you code your tables correctly, those things just can do wonders to a webpage. Now the one issue we’re having now with documents just kind of skipping back to this and this is on the mend, but Google docs have been very inaccessible in the past. Google is trying to make steps to improve this were coming up with more workarounds in JAWS or the iPhone, and fact not long ago I Google doc I could not access at all with JAWS and I thought, well let’s just look and see what happens if I pull it up on the iPhone and the thing was totally readable on the iPhone.

\n

So a lot of what you do when you come up with these documents or pages that might not be accessible is you experiment with the different technologies to see okay, which one works best? So you can almost say it's kind of playtime and that's great if you got a lot of time, but it would be a benefit if everybody would think accessibility because there times when you're in a hurry really don't have time to play with all your technology to see what works best.

\n

KEVIN: I understand. So as we finish up, go ahead and tell me the top three things that we could do to improve your web experience as a blind user Keith.

\n

KEITH: All right, well the top three things, first of all on webpages use headings. One of the things I like to do is browse a page by just looking at the various headings. And don't use them just for—use them to separate various types of information. Don't use them just as a thing that everything's under a heading because in that the weird stuff with the screen reader. But if you have a title, make it a Level 1 heading. If you have a subtitle, make a Level 2 heading or Level 3 or whatever. And that's the most helpful thing.

\n

Another thing is make sure tables are coded properly. A table can require a lot of memorization if you're blind if it's not coded properly and you can find some really good stuff out there on coding tables where the row headers, and column headers can be read with a screen reader very easily.

\n

The third thing that would be really helpful is if you've got graphics, if they are important to the content, if they’re meaningful to the content, put an “alt” tag on those graphics. Put an alt tag saying what they are; maybe even the long description of its really important use for “long desc” feature to put a description so that if the screen reader user hits a certain command they’ll get that description.

\n

And if it's a graphic that is just there for eye candy, that's fine, but in your “alt” tag, put “null” in there and make it just where the screen reader doesn’t even recognize it because the worst thing in the world would be reading a page and you hear, “graphic, graphic, graphic, graphic, graphic, graphic,” multiple times and you don't know what that graphic is. So there’s no problem using pictures at all; we encourage it but make sure that it’s “alt” tagged properly and if it's just eye candy make it a “null”.

\n

KEVIN: So you definitely want to have context with the images about, and how it relates to the page.

\n

KEITH: Exactly, exactly. On my own website for Keith Bundy Ministries, I have a picture of myself on there. And I just put an “alt” tag on there that said “picture of Keith Bundy” and you know, that way at least people were screen reader users know what the graphic is. You know there's a picture and it doesn't describe me or anything but they know there's a picture.

\n

KEVIN: Thanks again for your time!

\n

KEITH: Thank you Kevin; it is been my pleasure. I thoroughly enjoyed it.

\n
\n

\n

\nTop-Down, Bottom-up: 2 Approaches to Better Web Governance at Your University\n

\n

\nPosted by\nShane Diffily\n

\nFind me on:\n
\nTwitter \n
\n
\n

\n

\n4/10/14 1:49 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

I have heard it said that if a university was a country, it would last about a week before breaking apart in civil war. At first brush it sounded ridiculous, but now I think it actually makes a good bit of sense.

\n
\n

Think about it – a university:

\n
    \n
  • Has a large population.
    • \n
  • Is highly diverse.
    • \n
  • Is geographically distributed.
    • \n
  • Has lots of stakeholders and specialist interest groups.
    • \n
\n

So, short of calling out the troops, what can you do to get everyone acting in a unified way online?

\n

Enter ‘Web Governance’

\n

The purpose of Web Governance is to create stability in online operations.

\n

In an ideal system, all issues of ownership, authority, responsibility and resourcing are put to bed so you can focus your energies on pursuing online goals.

\n

For a small organization, this is usually quite manageable. All you need to keep the show on the road are a few informal procedures and some basic freeware tools.

\n

However, this type of informality does not scale well.

\n

For example, if the governance sophistication of a large university fails to keep pace with its online ambitions, things fall apart.

\n
    \n
  • In the absence of agreed-upon rules, solo-runs become common as individual colleges do their own thing, resulting in a wide diversity of technology and design.
    • \n
  • In the absence of skilled support, great disparities in the quality of experience emerge, as some sites are well maintained and others are ignored.
    • \n
\n
    \n
  • In the absence of necessary tools, no one can track what is happening online, exposing you to reputational risk.
    • \n
\n

There is a way out!

\n

The answer lies in recognizing that professionalism in Web Governance must keep pace with online ambition. In the first instance, this means adopting a more sophisticated top-down model of online management. Second, it means investing in better bottom-up supports for staff, to help them maintain quality.

\n

Let’s examine both of these approaches in more detail.

\n

Impose order from the top down

\n

A key problem on many large sites is that the complexity of operations overtakes the ability of a Web Manager to make sense of it. There are simply too many things going on.

\n

Adding to this, unlike other aspects of management (HR, finance, marketing, etc.), there is as yet little understanding of what exactly Web Governance is about.

\n

An essential first step, then, is to re-impose order on operations using a structured governance framework.

\n

Indeed, this approach can work particularly well in institutions of higher learning.

\n

Academics are used to dealing in frameworks and models, whether for physics, economics or politics. Explaining the needs and purpose of Web Governance in a similar way means you’re already speaking a language they understand.

\n

The new Framework of Web Governance describes all the elements needed to manage an online presence.

\n

The main benefit of this framework is that it reasserts order over complexity, and reveals interconnections that were once obscure by grouping similar elements together.

\n

Its second benefit is simplicity.

\n

The framework shows how everything to do with online management can be described in terms of just 3 elements. These are:

\n
    \n
  • Activity: This describes everything you must do to manage a website, no matter how big or small your site is.
    • \n
  • Resource: This describes everything you must invest in to make governance happen, e.g. people, tools, etc.
    • \n
  • Scale: This describes how to balance the Activities & Resources in a configuration of governance that works.
    • \n
\n

The simplicity of this framework makes it very effective as a communications tool when explaining what Web Governance is about to senior executives.

\n

\n

Read a complete introduction to the New Framework of Web Governance.

\n

It is also useful for contextualizing the roles & responsibilities of everyone involved in operations. This includes the many non-web staff typically involved in day-to-day maintenance, e.g. content publishers.

\n

This brings us to our second approach for improving Web Governance: bottom-up.

\n

Invest from the bottom up

\n

The clearest trend in Web Governance in recent years has been towards the centralization of digital activity.

\n

As noted by leading expert at Cap Gemini, Didier Bonnet: “Older Silo based operations … are coming under increasing pressure to change.”

\n

Several examples of this tendency can be seen within higher education, such as at RMIT in Australia and Harvard University, as well as in other sectors, such as government.

\n

The defining feature of this model is that nothing significant happens online without the say of the central digital unit.

\n

Well, almost nothing.

\n

Inevitably, there are instances where doing things centrally can actually inhibit progress, rather than assist it.

\n

The principle of subsidiarity states that in a highly distributed organization some activities should continue to be exercised at a local level. The challenge is allowing this to occur while still maintaining standards.

\n

This is where your new system of Web Governance must be backed-up by the supports staff need to do their jobs, e.g. online tools, process documentation, etc.

\n

In the last Siteimprove webinar, Ahava Leibtag of Aha Media Group referred to several items commonly used by content producers. The documentation and tools she described can have great utility in making subsidiarity work.

\n

The good news is that these aids can be extended far beyond publishing into other tasks of governance, e.g. quality assurance, performance monitoring, user engagement and more.

\n

Indeed, I recommend that supports of this type be packaged together into a Web Governance Toolkit for distribution among staff.

\n

\n

For example, such a toolkit may include:

\n
    \n
  • A step-by-step guide to creating a new website.
    • \n
  • A step-by-step guide to maintaining a website.
    • \n
  • A series of documented personas.
    • \n
  • An online style guide.
    • \n
  • A series of approved KPIs.
    • \n
  • Online access to approved tools, including CMS, Analytics, QA, Social monitoring, etc.
    • \n
\n

Visit diffily.com to download free samples from a Web Governance Toolkit.

\n

This material may be collected into printed ‘packs’ and presented to staff, perhaps at the start of a major development project or as a new site goes live. This means everyone has everything they need from the word go.

\n

When done well, a toolkit can endow your Web Team with enhanced credibility and reinforce your role as a guiding authority for online.

\n

Wait, there’s more

\n

So, we see that despite the challenges of Web Governance, there are ways to deal with it.

\n

Indeed, given the scale of the challenges, it is not surprising that some of the best solutions to online management arise within Higher Education.

\n

To learn more, be sure to tune in to my upcoming webinar on April 9th, “Top Down, Bottom Up: Two Approaches to Better Web Governance in Your University.”

\n

Shane has more than 14 years’ experience in Web Governance & online operations. As author of the first practical guide to Web Governance (“The Website Manager’s Handbook”), Shane has also been published by A List Apart, Smartinsights & Forrester Research. For lots of FREE Web Governance downloads, visit www.diffily.com.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

Q&A on the Basics of Web Accessibility

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n2/11/14 9:01 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n

We get a lot of questions on web accessibility here at Siteimprove, and want to take this opportunity to answer as many of them as we can. This may be more of a review for you seasoned accessibility folks, but there’s a growing demand for this introductory information as more web professionals recognize the importance of accessibility. 

\n

\n
\nRead More\n
\n
\n
\n

How to Win Friends and Influence Your Web Team

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n2/5/14 8:52 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n

Stop me if you’ve heard this one: You’re the website manager, and you’re held responsible for the quality of your web content - but you have content contributors from other departments over whom you hold no real power. That means you’re held accountable for the quality of their work, but have no way to make them actually do it. If they decide not to fix issues that come up, it reflects poorly on you. Fortunately, there are ways to manage this situation! Since you don’t have administrative influence over these team members, you’ll have to rely on relational influence – which is better anyway.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 8718663777:\n\n\n\n\n\nGet a head start by quality assuring your development site\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Blog

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\nGet a head start by quality assuring your development site\n

\n

\nPosted by\nCamilla Simonsen\n

\n

\n12/19/12 2:49 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Many of our customers launched new websites in 2012, and took advantage of running our Quality Assurance and Accessibility checks on the development website. Finding and fixing errors on their website prior to launching is helpful in it's own right, but allowing the web developers early access to the tools has proven to be invaluable.

\n
\n\n
\n
\n

In this blog post we encourage all customers working on a website redesign to collaborate with their web developers when quality assuring their new website.

\n
\n

Below are some recommendations and lessons learned from our customers which will hopefully make your life a little easier.

\n

Align expectations and roles

\n

Even though specification requirements state that your new website must comply with the standards of web accessibility, you can't expect to launch a flawless site. The web developer plays a crucial role in creating an accessible website, but a great deal of the responsibility lies on your shoulders too.

By aligning expectations and discussing roles with your web developer you'll get the best start at quality assuring your new website:

\n
    \n
  • Review the responsibilities of your web developer and clearly establish which areas the developers are responsible for, and what tasks rely on you and the web editors.
    • \n
  • Make sure to teach the web editors the relevant criteria of web accessibility before they start producing content for the new website in order to avoid common errors such as missing or duplicate page titles and headers and meaningless link phrases like 'click here', 'learn more' etc.
    • \n
  • Make sure that your web designer not only creates a visually appealing website, but also a design that takes users with disabilities into account. Typical challenges occur in navigation, use of colors, contrasts and headlines. You can learn more about what to look out for in last week's blog post: The Web Designer's Guide on How to Create Accessible GUIs.
    • \n
  • Develop your web governance: policies and procedures to ensure your webmasters and editors understand their individual responsibilities, and where to look for answers. You can take inspiration from our previous blog post: Web Governance policies and procedures.
    • \n
\n

Don't make the same mistake twice

\n

Developing a new website brings a fresh start, therefore it's a golden opportunity to get rid of previous bad habits and to fully quality assure your new site:

\n
    \n
  • Launch your new site with no broken links and misspellings. Whether you choose to rewrite or copy old content it's almost impossible to avoid broken links and spelling errors without some sort of automated assistance. We strongly encourage you to run a Quality Assurance check on your development website before launch.
    • \n
  • Run an Accessibility check of your main pages, such as the front page and other crucial templates, to check that the templates comply with the standards of accessibility. Make sure to share the results with your web developer and consider giving the developer access to your Siteimprove account during development. In most cases, all it takes to correct a problem are minor modifications in the CSS or in a template file, thus avoiding a recurrence of the mistake on its inherited pages.
    • \n
  • Consider whether you should choose a CMS setup with selected mandatory fields, such as page titles, meta descriptions and content editors to ensure uniformity across the website.
    • \n
\n

We'd love to hear your tips and tricks for how you quality assure a development site in the comments below.

\n

Want more tips & tricks?

\nDownload the Siteimprove White paper, 'Siteimprove during a website redesign'. 
\n

Download the Siteimprove white paper  'How to ensure website accessibility'.
\n
*Please note that pages 12-16 specify the different roles and relevant criteria for the web designers, web developers and web editors.
\n
\n
\n
\n \n \n
\n
\n

We are here to answer any questions you may have about our web governance tools and solutions. Don’t hesitate to get in contact with us. Drop us a line.

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 8689805157:\n\n\n\n\n\nPutting a Face on Accessibility\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n

\nPutting a Face on Accessibility\n

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n4/29/13 10:25 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

All too often we forget to put a face on people with disabilities, instead we lump them into categories.

\n
\n\n
\n

I’d like to introduce you to my friend Keith:

\n

Keith is a father and grandfather, a minister, and has been counseling troubled youth for over 30 years. He’s a diehard sports fan and spends his nights and weekends announcing games for the local college’s football, volleyball, basketball, and baseball teams.

\n

As a self-described technology buff, you’ll never find Keith without his iPhone. He loves taking pictures, especially of his new grandson. If you were to add Keith on Facebook, you could practically watch the boy grow up in his news feed. 

\n

Few people are as well traveled as Keith, who’s forever on a mission to become “mayor of everywhere” on Foursquare. Accompanying him on his adventures is his guide dog, a beautiful Black Labrador Retriever named Mercury.

\n

Keith is blind.

\n

Too often we forget to put a face on the people with disabilities. We lump them into categories:

\n
    \n
  • Blindness or Low Vision
    • \n
  • Deaf/Hard-of-Hearing
    • \n
  • Learning Disabilities
    • \n
  • Medical Disabilities
    • \n
  • Physical Disabilities
    • \n
\n

While these categories are conditions, they do not describe the individuals. They certainly do not describe Keith.

\n

Accessibility is something that is relevant for everyone working with websites regardless of whether you are a web designer, web developer, web manager, or web editor. As website specialists, we like to think we are pretty good at defining our audiences. Did you know that 20% of your users have some form of disability? One person out of five visiting your site has to do something out of the ordinary to get the information you’ve made available. Let’s look at this a different way—for every 1000 visitors, 200 may have difficulty with your site, or need an alternative way to get to your information. Alternative ways may include screen readers or screen magnifiers, braille readers, or keyboard only navigation.

\n

When you and your team redesigned your site the last time, did your UX designer include people with disabilities in the personas used for the site’s redesign? If you are not familiar with a persona, here is a brief description from Wikipedia:

\n

“In marketing and user-centered design, personas are fictional characters created to represent the different user types within a targeted demographic, attitude and/or behavior set that might use a site, brand or product in a similar way.”

\n

Personas are just one tool that can help with creating websites; to be effective your personas need to accurately reflect your visitors. If possible, engage a person with a disability to assist with persona creation, then re-engage your expert when it’s time to start testing the changes you’ve made to your site. For more information about creating accessible websites, read our blog posts “Web Editors: Create Accessible Websites”, “Web Developers: Create an Accessible Website”, and The Web Designer's Guide on How to Create Accessible GUIs.

\n

When you meet Keith, (or Bill, Sarah, or any other disabled person) for the first time, be sure to ask how much the grandson is growing, how their favorite sports team is doing, or about their latest hobby. If it’s Keith, be prepared to stop and chat for a while. He’s got some pictures to show you!

\n
\n
\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\nCorporate Responsibility at Siteimprove\n

\n

\nPosted by\nCamilla Simonsen\n

\n

\n4/25/12 11:21 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

At Siteimprove we work with Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) as an essential part of the growth we experience in our three main markets in the UK, USA and in Denmark. A lot of initiatives have already been introduced, for instance we work hard to contribute to a higher degree of Web Accessibility on public and private websites. We wish to minimize our carbon footprint and offer our employees a sound and exciting working environment, in order to encourage employees to create new and even better Web Governance solutions for our customers.

\n
\n\n

It's somewhat atypical for a software company like Siteimprove to be working with Corporate Social Responsibility. Our production isn't environmentally damaging and we don't have production or activities in Third World countries, however we do believe that all businesses, regardless of size, should contribute to the global environmental and social challenges. That being said it's also very important that our customers and partners know that we "behave properly."

\n

The last two years have been momentous to the company. The turnover has increased by 75%, the Siteimprove family has grown by 35 new employees and we're moving into three new markets in Canada, Sweden and Germany. This means that things are moving really fast in our three offices in Copenhagen, London and Minneapolis, which is exactly why it's important to ensure not only economical growth but also responsible growth.

\n

To demonstrate how serious we are on this matter, we joined the UN initiative Global Compact in 2010, and thereby commit ourselves to publish a yearly report (Communication on Progress) that gives an insight to the responsible initiatives we have worked with through the past year.

\n

The 3 main areas we work with within CSR: Human Rights, Labor, and Environment. A few of the main areas we have chosen to focus on are:

\n

Human Rights

\n

Contributing to a higher degree of Web Accessibility and thereby show regard to all types of Internet users in digitization.

\n
    \n
  • Free consultancy on Web Accessibility through blog posts, seminars and webinars.
    • \n
  • Pro Bono collaboration with an NGO to increase and disseminate knowledge about Web Accessibility. (Later we will give more details about the collaboration, which is still in its initial phase.)
    • \n
  • Optimization of the 'Siteimprove Accessibility' service, which makes it easier for webmaster on all levels to offer users accessible websites that meet international standards for accessibility (WCAG 2.0).
    • \n
\n
    \n
  • Climate & Environment: To reduce our energy consumption and carbon footprint
    • \n
\n
    \n
  • Siteimprove have signed a climate partnership agreement with DONG Energy, (the leading energy company in Denmark) which means that we have identified our energy consumption and saving potential and continuously work in a number of areas in order to ensure that Siteimprove becomes a more sustainable company.
    • \n
\n

Labor

\n
To ensure happy employees who offer customers excellent products and great service
\n
    \n
  • The sharp minds of the Siteimprove employees is our core business, as all our 'production' takes place in the brains of our employees. 
    • \n
  • A prerequisite for being able to offer customers excellent products and great service is that we can attract and retain qualified employees by offering a sound working environment.
    • \n
\n

 

\n

Do you want to know more or let us know what you think?

\n

CSR is still a new world to us. In 2011 we published the first Siteimprove Responsibility Report, which gives you an insight into what we do. We welcome any feedback and ideas on how to strengthen our corporate social responsibility in the future - the second Responsibility Report is just around the corner.

\n

Please feel free to email interesting ideas directly to the CSR manager Camilla Simonsen at cas@siteimprove.dk

\n

 

\n
\n

\n

How to Stop Putting Out Fires and be Proactive With Your Website

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n4/10/14 11:24 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Everyone knows reactive marketing is ineffective, but far too many marketers are buried deep under a pile of emergencies to even think about strategic planning. What do you do when your boss comes to your desk every day to light your hair on fire with another emergency?

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Why Content Governance Drives Engagement

\n

\nPosted by\nAhava Leibtag\n

\n

\n4/10/14 10:34 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

In honor of President’s Day, my husband and I took our three children to the American Museum of History, a branch of the Smithsonian in Washington, D.C. While we were putting our coats in lockers, I saw something that surprised me:

\n
\n

Does stash seem like a word that is in line with Smithsonian brand? Stash feels a little too irreverent to be a Smithsonian word. Yet, when I saw this sign, it became clear to me:

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

How to Win Friends and Influence Your Web Team

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n2/5/14 8:52 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n

Stop me if you’ve heard this one: You’re the website manager, and you’re held responsible for the quality of your web content - but you have content contributors from other departments over whom you hold no real power. That means you’re held accountable for the quality of their work, but have no way to make them actually do it. If they decide not to fix issues that come up, it reflects poorly on you. Fortunately, there are ways to manage this situation! Since you don’t have administrative influence over these team members, you’ll have to rely on relational influence – which is better anyway.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

6 Ways to Catch Website Issues Before They're a Problem

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n1/28/14 9:04 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n

Issues with your website can be absolutely devastating. Despite any of the marketing momentum or client base that you've built up, you may find your traffic ranking and following drastically tanking due to website errors. Lag, bad links, a lack of accessibility and even outdated content can quickly damage a website's SEO and lose the faith of its readership. Luckily, there are some ways you can avoid these issues before they even become a problem.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n

How Maintaining Your Website Saves Time and Headache

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n1/16/14 9:19 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n

“I don’t have time to quality assure my site. I’m already swamped with too many other things, and that’ll just have to wait until life settles down a bit.” Sound familiar? Time management is a daily struggle for most website managers, and all too often they deal with pressing deadlines by turning a blind eye to the quality of their website content. Unsurprisingly, this usually doesn't go well. Here are three good reasons why you actually need to keep your site the cleanest when you’re buried under a heavy workload:

\n
\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Siteimprove Announces US Relocation

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n1/14/14 3:41 AM\n

\n
\n\n

    \n

    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n

Siteimprove, the leading provider of Web Governance tools, has relocated their Minneapolis office due to rapid growth in 2013.

\n
\n
\n

On January 2, 2014, Siteimprove US moved into a new office located at 8000 Norman Center Drive, Suite 300, Minneapolis, MN 55437 as part of a major workforce expansion.

\n

Siteimprove’s Minneapolis branch grew significantly in 2013, adding more than 250 new customers and 13 employees.

\n

\n
\n
\n

Website redesigns tend to be treated as a magic cure for a poor web presence by many digital marketers today. Unfortunately for them, separating fact from fiction can be a sobering wake up call. Here are the top 4 myths surrounding website redesign projects today:

5 Reasons You Should Care About Website Errors You're Not Responsible For

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n12/10/13 9:42 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

If an issue on your organization’s website doesn't fall under your area of responsibility, then it’s not your problem, right? Not so fast. Being part of a successful web team means ensuring the entire site is cohesive and error free. That means setting aside the mindset of “not my area, not my fault” and working with your teammates. Because guess what? A problem you pretend not to notice might just land in your lap later on. Here’s why you should care about mistakes in someone else’s jurisdiction. 

\n
\nRead More\n

Siteimprove Wins J. Boye Web Idol of the Year Award!

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n11/12/13 10:58 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Last Wednesday, November 6th, 2013, Siteimprove was honored to be able to compete in the annual J.Boye conference ‘Web Idol’ competition. Held in Aarhus, Denmark, the conference is a series of international events that aim to bring web practitioners together in an informative environment that fosters relationships and encourages knowledge sharing.

\n

Producing High-Quality Web Content: A Guided Tour

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n12/9/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

If you're one of those people who can just wake up in the morning, pour yourself a cup of your preferred breakfast-time libation, and start pounding away at your keyboard until something great comes out, we’re officially fighting and I’d like you to leave now.

\n

OK, good. They’re gone.

\n

For us common-folk, creating great content takes time, and it doesn’t happen in a vacuum. It requires a team-effort, as you’ll need input from subject matter experts and buy-in from your co-workers/bosses in order to turn a slab of rock into a piece of chiseled marble.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Web Content, Your Audience, and Search Engines

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n10/28/14 10:03 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Quality over quantity, right? “But wait”, you say. “I thought that adding more content and blogs would help boost my site’s SEO rankings?” Well, yes and no. Simply cramming your website full of unfocused, aimless ramblings is actually a sure fire way to earn the ire of both your readers and that company whose name rhymes with “Moogle”. It’s Google. I’m talking about Google.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

4 Tips For A Fall Website Cleanup

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n10/7/14 10:02 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Clutter is OK on your desk. Sure, your co-workers will be silently (or not so silently) judging you as stacks of paper, coffee cups, and assorted knick-knacks pile up around your keyboard like garbage in a landfill, but it’s part of your process, right?

\n

Your website, on the other hand, is no place for clutter. Customers expect simple navigation, easy to find information, and useful content. If your website took the summer off to relax, it’s time to put it back to work.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

3 Tips For Creating An Effective Website Content Calendar

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n9/30/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

With the demand for consistent, high-quality web content growing on a daily basis, creating a Content Calendar is the best way to coordinate and organize your content marketing efforts and ensure that your brand remains top of mind with your core audience.

\n

Content Calendars will vary from organization to organization, but by compiling all of your goals, assets, and ideas in a single document, you’ll be able to piece together what can turn into an otherwise unruly and chaotic puzzle.

\n

Ready? Set? Go.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent,\nWebsite Redesign\n

Website SEO Checklist

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n9/9/14 10:05 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

What Google says, goes. They are the Alpha and Omega when it comes to online search, and their search algorithm is what dictates how your website’s SEO needs to be calibrated. In order to receive the maximum return on your online investment, your website’s SEO needs to cross off a number of key to-do’s before it can reap the rewards from Skynet Google.

\n

If you haven’t been keeping up with Google’s latest algorithm updates, read our blog that discussed the evolving SEO landscape. Go ahead and read it, I’ll wait.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance\n

The Foundations of a Website Redesign

\n

\nPosted by\nStar Bazella\n

\n

\n8/19/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Embarking on a website redesign is no small undertaking. It will require a substantial amount of strategy, organization, and company soul-searching. Not only will you need to ask difficult questions, but you’ll need to provide answers that satisfy every major stakeholder. This prospect alone is enough to deter some organizations from pressing forward, but there are steps you can take in order to not only streamline your redesign project, but ensure that everyone’s needs are met.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nWebsite Redesign\n

\n
\n
\n

How To Quickly Clean Up Disorganized Web Content

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n7/8/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

\n
\n

If you’re feeling overwhelmed by the prospect of cleaning up your website content, the suggestion to “get an overview of your content” may sound glib and unhelpful, but it really doesn’t need to be more complicated than that.

\n
\n

There are plenty of tools available to assist you in putting together an overview, so there’s no reason to ever waste your time manually creating a website inventory.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n

5 Reasons Why Your Website Content Isn’t Influencing Readers

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n7/1/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Humanizing the digital world is no simple task. Thanks to the rapid advances in technology, the expansion of social media, and the ever growing influence of the Internet, consumers are growing more and more savvy by the day. They also have more choices than ever before, which means you have more competition than ever before. So the question becomes, how to distance yourself from competitors and convince consumers that your product/service/organization is the best option for them?

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Why Blogging Should Be Part Of Your Web Governance Strategy

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n6/24/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

The “too long; didn’t read” version? It’s good for business. Oh, you’re still there. Well then let’s elaborate on that a little bit. When done correctly, blogging is arguably the most important, and most effective, inbound marketing tactic your organization can utilize. According to HubSpot, blogging regularly will result in more sales leads, more site visits, and more social media engagement. See? We told you it’s good for business.

\n

Now, for you detail-oriented readers, let’s take a closer look at how blogging can have a positive impact on your other marketing and web governance strategies and help you reach your online marketing goals.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Content Marketing and Website Governance are, like, Totally BFFs

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n6/10/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

“Keep telling me what to do and what to buy”, said no consumer ever. Mass marketing tactics such as TV, print, and radio were once the staples of every marketing strategy. But, thanks to the Internet, they have seen their share of the budget eaten away by a new brand of more carefully curated strategies that are able to leverage websites, social media, and email. One such strategy is Content Marketing, which aims to attract a highly targeted audience by developing and sharing content that has been designed specifically with them in mind.   

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n

\n\n\n 9089754317:XML-RPC server accepts POST requests only. 8892183907:\n\n\n\n\n\nHow Web Accessibility Can Boost Your SEO\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n

\nHow Web Accessibility Can Boost Your SEO\n

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n10/6/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

In case having a website that’s accessible to all users wasn’t enough incentive on its own, here’s another reason- it will help boost your SEO rankings. Yeah, true story. On the surface it may not seem like the two are connected, but behind the subtle scenes of your website’s code, proper accessibility practices are providing a major boost to your SEO. What’s that idiom about birds and stones? 

\n\n

Website accessibility means creating an online environment in which all users, not just those with disabilities, are able to easily navigate, interact with, and understand the web. Having a website that features intuitive navigation, properly labeled links and images, and user friendly design aesthetics will result in users spending more time on your site, consuming your content, and engaging with your brand. For more information on web accessibility, read our various web accessibility blogs

\n

SEO refers to the curation of your site’s content in order to enhance your ranking in organic web searches. However, Google continues to adjust their search algorithm in order to combat dishonest SEO practices, like keyword stuffing and link building, so you’ll want to make sure you’re up to speed on the latest rules by reading our blog about the evolving SEO landscape.

\n

It may seem daunting, but the good news is that you can improve your site’s accessibility and SEO without needing to be a professional web developer or SEO expert. Let’s take a look at some of the ways in which you can improve your site’s accessibility and SEO today.

\n

If you like what you read here, be sure to download the Accessibility & SEO Webinar from our Senior eAccessibility Consultant, Kevin Rydberg.

\n

Link Text

\n

How it Impacts Human Users & Assistive Devices

\n

Link text refers to the hyperlinked words, phrases, or sentences within page content. This text is intended to inform users of where the link will be taking them, or the type of content to which the link is directed.

\n

Link text should be as descriptive as possible in order to avoid confusion and frustration. Clicking the “back” button in your browser may not seem like a complicated task for many of you, but for physically or visually impaired users, it may not be so simple.

\n

Another reason to provide detailed link text is that screen readers allow visually impaired users to navigate webpages via a list of internal links, so ten links all titled “Click Here” would be of no help.

\n

“Click here” or “Read more” = Bad Link Text

\n

“Read more about SEO and Web Accessibility” = Good Link Text

\n

How it Impacts Search Engines

\n

Link text also informs search engines of where hyperlinks are directed, but, like screen readers or text-to-speech platforms, they are only able to read the HTML code verbatim, they can’t imply a destination based on associated text. Context matters to search engines, particularly Google, who are now rewarding sites which provide high-quality content and links to other reputable sites.

\n

If your link text reads, “Click here”, the search engine will interpret this as the title or subject of the page to which you're linking. More specific link text, such as, “See the Top 10 Vacation Destinations”, allows the search engine to identify Vacation Destinations as the topic and factor it into your site’s ranking when users search for “Vacations” or “Vacation Destinations”

\n

Image Descriptions

\n

How it Impacts Human Users & Assistive Devices

\n

Screen readers don’t have eyes. They navigate sites by reading the HTML code, and image descriptions enable them to identify what the image is depicting and properly relay that information to users.

\n

Take the image below. While it may be obvious to some users that the image is showing the Chrysler Building and downtown Manhattan, it is not obvious to assistive devices like screen readers or text-to-speech software.

\n

\n

The assistive device only knows that this is an image because the code used to embed this image on a website uses the HTML image <img> tag, which looks like this:

\n

<img src="images/071014-DSC_01.jpg"/>

\n

However, this still does not tell the screen reader what the image is depicting. In order to help, you should rename the file with a descriptive filename, as well as adding some alternative, or “alt” text to the <img> tag, like so:

\n

<img src="images/chrysler_building.jpg" alt="View of Manhattan and the Chrysler Building"/>

\n

This alternative text is also useful for users with a slow internet connection, incompatible web browser, or who have chosen to not load images, as it provides a description of the image even if it isn’t loaded. A further description of the function of the “alt” attributes can be found on the W3C website.

\n

Another not-so-fun fact: Without “alt” text, devices like screen readers will read the image file name word for word, number for number, and character for character, even if it's complete jibberish. However, if it identifies “alt” text within the HTML, it will automatically skip to this text and save the user from a potentially frustrating and confusing situation.

\n

How it Impacts Search Engines

\n

Image descriptions are just as important for search engines. By providing an accurate file name and descriptive “alt” text, search engines will be able to identify that your site includes relevant images that support its content and reward you for its relevancy.

\n

Semantic Markup

\n

How it Impacts Human Users & Assistive Devices

\n

Semantic Markup refers to the practice of employing properly structured HTML code which clearly identifies the content sections of your site, like headers, navigation, articles, footers, etc. Doing so will give your website a logical layout that is easy for both human users and assistive devices to navigate.

\n

Proper site navigation results in a better experience where content and information are easy to find, interact with, and understand. Being able to find what they're looking for means more user time spent on your site, which results in higher SEO rankings.

\n

How it Impacts Search Engines

\n

Search engines crawl websites’ HTML systematically; they start at the top and work their way down. So if your most important content is clearly labeled near the top of the page’s HTML (page headers/navigation), the search engine will be able to easily identify what your page content is all about and reflect that in your SEO ranking.

\n

Hopefully this blog was able to help you improve your website's accessibility and SEO practices, but feel free to post and questions or feedback in the comments section below!

\n
\n

 

\n

Our Senior eAccessibility Consultant, Kevin Rydberg recently recorded an on-demand webinar that covers how Web Accessibility can boost your SEO.

\n

  \n \n \n

\n
\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nAccessibility\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 8914246467:\n\n\n\n\n\nCognitive Disabilities and Website Accessibility\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n

\nCognitive Disabilities and Website Accessibility\n

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n8/12/14 9:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

While sight and hearing disabilities are the most talked-about when it comes to website accessibility, cognitive disabilities actually represent the largest number of computer users with disabilities according to the National Center on Disability and Access to Education.

\n

So, why aren’t we more aware of cognitive disabilities? Well, because these types of disabilities contain a wide range of nuanced conditions and an even wider range of severity, so it’s difficult to present a comprehensive set of standards to which web developers should comply. 

\n

\n

Let's break down some of the different aspects of cognitive disorders. First:

\n

What Are Cognitive Disabilities?

\n

Simply put, Cognitive Disabilities are any and all conditions or impairments that inhibit a person's mental process. The variations in type and severity are too great to list here, but many of these conditions are ones that we see and experience on a daily basis.

\n

Functional vs. Clinical Cognitive Disorders

\n

Cognitive disorders may be classified in two different ways, functional or clinical. Functional disorders focus more on the person’s abilities and which trials they face in their day-to-day lives. Some examples of functional disabilities include:

\n
    \n
  • Memory
    • \n
  • Attention
    • \n
  • Comprehension
    • \n
\n

Clinical disorders vary widely in severity, and how an individual may function. Examples of clinical disorders include:

\n
    \n
  • Autism
    • \n
  • Traumatic Brain Injury (TBI)
    • \n
  • Dyslexia
    • \n
\n

From our perspective as web developers, it’s better to think about cognitive disorders purely from a functional consideration. Why? For one simple reason: as developers we can focus on the barriers, not the diagnosis. By thinking about and presenting solutions, we can focus on improving our user’s experience.

\n

Ideas for Cognitive Web Accessibility

\n

Simply by following good design, content, and coding practices, we can improve the user experience for many people with cognitive disorders. We often talk about coding and specific things like semantic markup, and while we need to continue to think about these techniques, we also want to think about what is showing up on the screen.

\n

When considering visual styles as well as content organization, we can improve the user experience by:

\n
    \n
  • Using proper headings, and lists
    • \n
  • Using more white space in your design
    • \n
  • “Chunking” content into more manageable pieces
    • \n
  • Making forms manageable by breaking them into multiple, sequential steps
    • \n
  • Providing a logical reading order
    • \n
  • Being consistent with fonts, colors, and locations of page elements
    • \n
  • Offering keyboard access
    • \n
  • Consider offering content in multiple formats
    • \n
\n

 

\n

Want to learn more about accessibility and cognitive disabilities?

\n

Addressing cognitive disorders on your website should be a large consideration within your accessibility strategy. Please join us for our webinar on August 20 for a more information about planning for cognitive disabilities when managing your website.

\n

  \n \n \n

\n

Image courtesy of bluebay at FreeDigitalPhotos.net

\n
\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n

About Siteimprove

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Suite: The only web governance software that helps you better manage and maintain your website through quality assurance, accessibility, web analytics, SEO, and response – all in one tool.

Website Benchmarking Study: Law Firms

Mistakes are costly.

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

Your website is the prospective client's first stop when evaluating attorneys, and usability errors like broken links and misspellings destroy credibility. When looking for meticulous and timely legal support, who wouldn't have a difficult time overlooking a 404 error when signing up for a client alert, or finding the word "Technolgy" under your list of practices?

\n

This study provides benchmarking for your legal service's website quality standards.

\n
\n

Issues examined in this study:

\n
\n
    \n
  • Broken links
    • \n
  • Misspellings
    • \n
  • SEO-damaging issues
    • \n
\n



\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n \n\n\n 9028100927:\n\n\n\n\n\nWhy Making PDF Accessible Documents is Important\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

On-Demand Webinar: Why Making PDF Accessible Documents is Important

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

Making your PDF documents accessible is important so that all users are able to access your information—no matter its format. Not only is making your content accessible a best practice, some companies are also required to maintain accessibility and follow standards from Section 508 of the Rehabilitation Act as amended in 1998.

\n

What you will learn:                                                    

\n
    \n
  • Why and How to define an accessible document
    • \n
  • When to use vs. not use PDF files
    • \n
  • Alternatives for PDF content
    • \n
  • Where to start when creating PDF documents
    • \n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\n
\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Latest news.

\n

Your one stop spot for all the latest news about what we’ve been up to, what we plan on doing, plus plenty of extra exciting announcements about everything from web governance news, customer visits, partnerships, sponsorship’s, awards and much more.

Siteimprove Sailors Set for Success

\n
\n

BY Star Bazella

\n

4. Aug 2014

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

The Siteimprove Sailing Team today sets off to compete in the highly anticipated ORC International World Championship tournament, which takes place in Kiel, Germany, from August 1st until August 9th, 2014.

\n

With a strong 11-man roster, the Siteimprove Sailing Team is ready to show that web governance isn’t the only thing Siteimprove excels at. After three years of intense training and with a number of friendly wins under their belt, the team is ready for their first appearance at the World Championship.

\n

Decked out in Siteimprove clothing and with the Siteimprove flag flying proudly in the wind, Siteimprove employee and crew member David Flygenring Nielsen is confident they will come home the winners.

\n

“First and foremost we’re a competitive team that likes to win, and with all of Siteimprove behind us I feel confident we’re going to make everyone proud.”

\n

For Siteimprove CEO Morten Ebbesen, the opportunity to sponsor the Siteimprove Sailing Team wasn’t just about winning.

\n

“As a growing international company that prides itself on supporting employees’ work-life balance this seemed like a great chance to take our commitment to health and well being to a new level”, said Ebbesen. “It’s great that David is getting out there and being active, plus the event itself is bound to be a lot of fun, which is something we strongly support in our own workplace, so the values align”.

\n

The Siteimprove Sailing Team will provide regular updates throughout the competition, so join us in supporting them on their journey to success by checking out #ORCworlds #siteimprovesailing

\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

Siteimprove To Assist Minnesota Wild With Their Web Governance Goal

\n

MINNEAPOLIS, MN – November 19, 2014: Siteimprove announced today that they have partnered with the Minnesota Wild of the National Hockey League to use Siteimprove’s web governance suite, offered via Software as a Service (SaaS). Web governance is the practice of managing the quality and consistency of your online presence through organized systems, policies, and…

\n

BY Callan Young

\n

20. Nov 2014

Siteimprove Releases New Trademark Monitoring Feature for Web Governance Suite

\n

Today, Siteimprove launched a new feature within their Web Governance Suite that enables users to monitor for consistent Trademark usage. This new feature allows users to ensure that names, copyrights, and trademarks are presented accurately according to organizational standards. Protecting intellectual property is essential in today’s constantly evolving digital marketplace, yet many organizations lack the…

\n
\n

\n

Siteimprove Promotes From Within, Names New VP of Customer Success

\n

Software as a service (SaaS) company, Siteimprove, has named Steve Hennigs as their new Vice President of Customer Success. Hennigs has been with Siteimprove since opening their U.S. office in 2007 and previously occupied the role of Senior Product Specialist. Hennigs will be heading up the newly created Customer Success Team, which will aim to…

\n
\n

\n

8. Sep 2014
