An accessible website minus the confusion

\n

Web Accessibility is about allowing people with and without disabilities to have access to the information they want and need from your website. With reports of 1 in 5 people in North America claiming some sort of disability, 20% of the population is just too large of a group to ignore. Siteimprove Accessibility gives you a complete overview of your site’s web accessibility issues, plus clear explanations of how they affect your users, and specific recommendations on how to fix them.

\nRequest a Demo\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

But where do I even begin with Web Accessibility?

\n

Web Accessibility can seem overwhelming but with our simple tool, it need not be a hassle. With explanations written by an actual person and issues broken down into easily understandable categories it is the stress-free way to ensure your site(s) accessibility at your own pace.

\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
    \n
  • \n
    \n

    How does it work?

    \n

    Siteimprove automatically runs a scan of your entire website or specified sections of web content (including PDF documents) every 5 days and manually as needed. This highlights any WCAG 2.0 current issues which can be automatically detected as a result of evolving and dynamic content.

    \n
    \n
    \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n

    Check online PDF document accessibility errors

    \n

    As well as scanning web pages for WCAG 2.0 accessibility issues Siteimprove Accessibility also scans all of your site’s PDFs for detectable issues as part of WCAG 2.0 / ISO 14289-1:2012 / Matterhorn Protocol. This includes full document and single page element accessibility issues affecting usability, from missing headings and bookmarks to images without alternative text.

    \n
    \n
    \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n

    Check website accessibility issues WCAG 2.0

    \n

    Issues and Guidelines in Siteimprove Accessibility checks and identifies the WCAG 2.0 success criteria conformance levels A, AA and AAA for ensuring accessible web content. For instance, missing text alternatives, such as success criteria 1.1.1 Non-text Content which affects screen readers accessing images and even search engine performance. Siteimprove Accessibility also helps list and prioritize errors, flags warnings and allows you to review and ignore WGAG 2.0 issues accordingly.

    \n
    \n
    \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n

    Understand Your Task List

    \n

    Get a simple explanation of how each issue affects your users, and how to address the problem. Plus sort issues by page, issue type, or guideline numbers to stay organized with ease.

    \n
    \n
    \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n

    Web accessibility issues highlighted directly on-page

    \n

    For efficient inspection, every website and PDF accessibility issue is highlighted and reported directly on-page and includes clear explanations of issue type and instructions for how to fix them.

    \n
    \n
    \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n

    Simple HTML and CSS W3C web page validation

    \n

    Siteimprove Accessibility Issues and Guidelines also checks and evaluates your website’s HTML and CSS markup in conformance with W3C standards to quickly identify those portions of your website that need your attention. Code which is marked up in line with W3C is seen as good web practice and improves website accessibility and search engine visibility.

    \n
    \n
    \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n

    Schedule, export and customize Accessibility reports

    \n

    Siteimprove Accessibility customized reports are delivered directly to your inbox, while prioritized error lists help direct your attention to where it’s needed most. You can also export data directly from specific features into MS Excel and XML format, and generate and customize unlimited report templates to suit the needs of you and your team.

    \n
    \n
    \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

The Siteimprove Customer Experience

\n

Online support services - Access product information, software updates and technical support resources online within the tool.

\n

Expert technical assistance - Siteimprove’s trained Customer Experience team is available to provide free expert advice and assistance for all your training and support needs.

\n

Full upgrade protection - Software upgrades and documentation are free, ensuring you stay current on the latest technical developments.

\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n 9028095097:\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nWhy work for Siteimprove?\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n \n\n\n\n\n\n\n

Why work for Siteimprove?

\n

Siteimprove has provided thousands of organizations with web-based tools to organize and maintain their large websites since 2003 – and business is booming. What started as four young go-getters coding in Copenhagen, Denmark has matured into a successful enterprise with offices in Copenhagen, London, and Minneapolis, and thousands of customers in well over a dozen countries. We’re growing like a weed. A good weed… maybe a Sunflower?

\n

When that Sunflower was transplanted into Minneapolis in 2007, it took root quickly. (Puns, anyone?) Siteimprove now proudly serves more than a 1000+ organizations in North America, ranging from small one-person web teams to Fortune 500 Companies.

\n

See open opportunities

\n

\n

Culture

\n

Here at Siteimprove we’re people first. So what does that buzzwordish-sounding phrase mean? It means our management philosophies focus more on how much you can accomplish than how late you stay in the office, and more on your bright ideas than the shine of your shoes. We also believe that happy people work better, and constantly find reasons to celebrate with each other. Birthday celebrations, holiday parties, and community outreach projects are a regular part of life here.

\n

\n

Opportunity

\n

Siteimprove is growing by leaps and bounds, helping website managers to refine the way they maintain their sites. The Minneapolis office is looking for hardworking, lighthearted individuals to grow with us as we preach the good news of Website Governance. Siteimprove is committed to placing the best people, empowering them to succeed and promoting from within. Check out the open positions to see how you can join the Siteimprove team by clicking the “See open positions” button below. We’re excited to meet you!

\n

Benefits

\n

Paid Holidays, Paid Time Off, 401K + Company Match, Medical Benefits, Dental Benefits, our infamous “Stretch-improve” Sessions, Onsite Fitness Center, Company Sponsored Events, Training and Development, Progressive Office Culture, Access to Management and the list goes on!

\n

See open opportunities

\n
\n

\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Financial

\n

Financial institutions face tremendous pressure to comply with strict regulations. If the privacy policy link breaks, web pages aren’t accessible to disabled users, or words are misspelled, your site could lose business (and be vulnerable to litigation!) Even worse, web analytics tools are too complex to be useful without a bottomless training budget. Siteimprove can help!

\nRequest a Demo\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

Siteimprove for Financial

\n

Siteimprove’s Web Governance Suite, offered via Software as a Service [SaaS], helps organizations manage and maintain their websites through web quality assurance, web accessibility, web analytics, SEO analysis and web performance alerts.

\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
    \n
  • \n
    \n

    Check website accessibility issues WCAG 2.0

    \n

    Issues and Guidelines in Siteimprove Accessibility checks and identifies the WCAG 2.0 success criteria conformance levels A, AA and AAA for ensuring accessible web content. For instance, missing text alternatives, such as success criteria 1.1.1 Non-text Content which affects screen readers accessing images and even search engine performance. Siteimprove Accessibility also helps list and prioritize errors, flags warnings and allows you to review and ignore WGAG 2.0 issues accordingly.

    \n
    \n
    \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n

    Quickly Identify Broken Links

    \n

    Siteimprove’s crawlers check every link on every single page of your site so that you don’t have to. With options to filter broken links by internal and external, you can quickly see where the problem lies. Plus run reports at any time to instantly see your progress.

    \n
    \n
    \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n

    Stress-free Language Management

    \n

    Easily see every spelling mistake on your website, and utilize the powerful dictionary editing features to eliminate false positives and proactively flag inappropriate words. Plus if you were to accidentally add a misspelled word to the dictionary it’s no problem as all changes can be reviewed and edited.

    \n
    \n
    \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n

    Manage keywords and page optimization relationships

    \n

    Siteimprove SEO Keywords helps monitor your website’s target keywords on their corresponding pages and indicates average Google rankings so you can effectively optimize page by page. Additionally, Page Analyses functionality helps provide meaningful keyword score data, based on content SEO issues, ranking, visits from search engines and bounce rate. Plus this data also provides useful keyword suggestions taken from organic search results, so you can determine which keywords you should be optimizing for using Siteimprove SEO.

    \n
    \n
    \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n

    Schedule and Customize Reports

    \n

    Siteimprove Quality Assurance custom reports are delivered directly to your inbox, with prioritized error lists directing your attention to where it’s needed most. Plus generate, schedule and customize unlimited report templates to suit you or your staff’s needs.

    \n
    \n
    \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

\n
\n
    \n
  • \n

Happy clients

\n

Here's what they have to say about us

\n
\n
    \n
  • \n
    \n\n
    \n

    As a one-person marketing team, Siteimprove helps me work smarter, not harder. The easy interface and daily reports make it easy to find website errors before customers do. Don’t overlook the opportunity to have a web quality control source so easily available to you!

    \n
    \nMarketing Director at Senn Delaney Leadership Consulting Group, LLC.
    \n
    \n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n\n
    \n

    Siteimprove Quality Assurance, quite simply put is indispensable. I manage a higher ed website with thousands of pages and since incorporating Siteimprove into our maintenance schedule I have confidence that users will not find broken links or spelling errors, both which erode our credibility as an institution of higher learning. Whether a broken link is the result of a change from an external site we are linked to or a domino effect from something we have done elsewhere on the site, Siteimprove alerts us to the problem and we can address the issue quickly. The ability to segment and share the reports enables those closest to specific content to be involved in a productive and expedient way.

    \n
    \nAssistant Director of Communications at Cornell University
    \n
    \n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n\n
    \n

    It rarely happens, but when a service does what it says and provides an immediate positive impact by both saving staff time and enhancing our reputation, I feel compelled to let people know about it. I am thoroughly impressed with Siteimprove and have recommended it very highly to others. Thank you for an excellent product and keep up the good work.

    \n
    \nCIO / Director of IT Services at Metropolitan Government of Nashville and Davidson County

\n\n\n\n\n\n 9477018117:\n\n\n\n\n\nSiteimprove Webinar: 3 Necessary Activities & Skills for Effective Web Analytics\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

\n\n

\n

On-Demand Webinar: 3 Necessary Activities & Skills for Effective Web Analytics

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

It is hard to get an effective web analytics program off the ground, and even harder without a proper understanding of what you need.

\n

In this on-demand webinar Steve Hennigs, Vice President of Customer Success at Siteimprove, explores and identifies the three main activities and three required skills your team needs to ensure you move away from just looking at reports and move towards understanding how to improve your website.

\n

By the end of this webinar, you will have a better grasp on what you need to invest in and how to allocate your resources to effectively analyze your organization’s digital presence.

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\n\n\n

\n\n

\n

\n

Greater Baltimore Medical Center

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

Thank you for requesting our case study!

\n


Click to Download the case study HERE

\n


This case study gives a brief explanation of how Greater Baltimore Medical Center uses Siteimprove to improve patient education with web governance in their organization. 

\n
\n

Like to learn more? Click to Request a Demo

\n

Managing websites can be tricky, especially the more pages it has, and the more people responsible for its content.

\n

Siteimprove’s Web Governance Suite helps organizations manage and maintain their websites through:

\n
    \n
  • Web Quality Assurance
    • \n
  • Web Accessibility
    • \n
  • Web Analytics
    • \n
  • Search Engine Optimization Analysis
    • \n
  • Web Performance Alerts
    • \n

\n

Why You Might Want To Rethink That Website Redesign

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n1/6/15 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Redesigning your website and expecting all of your problems to disappear is like buying a new house because you’re too lazy to clean the one you live in now. Oh, it'll look nice for a while, but eventually you’ll be up to your armpits in clutter again. The same goes for your website. Slapping on a fresh coat of paint might make it look shiny and sleek, but the fundamental problems will remain below the surface.

\n

Spending time, money, and energy on driving traffic to a broken website is a massive waste of resources. Users might be flooding your site, but if all they find are broken links, poor navigation, a lack of direction, and accessibility issues, the frustrating experience will turn them off for good.

\n

The good news? These are all issues that can be addressed on your existing site. So, what can you do instead?

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance,\nContent,\nWebsite Redesign,\nWeb Design\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Website Redesign Checklist

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n11/11/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Website redesign. Those two simple words are enough to make even the most seasoned of marketers break out into a cold sweat. Research, planning, meetings, debates, design, user experience, content, development, approvals, and that’s just the process for deciding whether or not you should do a redesign. The sheer amount of work needed to pull off a website redesign is often all it takes to make companies reconsider the whole idea, but it doesn’t have to be.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nWebsite Redesign\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

3 Tips For Creating An Effective Website Content Calendar

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n9/30/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

With the demand for consistent, high-quality web content growing on a daily basis, creating a Content Calendar is the best way to coordinate and organize your content marketing efforts and ensure that your brand remains top of mind with your core audience.

\n

Content Calendars will vary from organization to organization, but by compiling all of your goals, assets, and ideas in a single document, you’ll be able to piece together what can turn into an otherwise unruly and chaotic puzzle.

\n

Ready? Set? Go.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent,\nWebsite Redesign\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

The Foundations of a Website Redesign

\n

\nPosted by\nStar Bazella\n

\n

\n8/19/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Embarking on a website redesign is no small undertaking. It will require a substantial amount of strategy, organization, and company soul-searching. Not only will you need to ask difficult questions, but you’ll need to provide answers that satisfy every major stakeholder. This prospect alone is enough to deter some organizations from pressing forward, but there are steps you can take in order to not only streamline your redesign project, but ensure that everyone’s needs are met.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nWebsite Redesign\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

3 Tips for Preparing for a Website Redesign

\n

\nPosted by\nStar Bazella\n

\n

\n4/10/14 10:16 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Website redesign projects are all the rage in marketing today. According to recent studies, the vast majority of marketing departments have either just undergone a website redesign, or are just about to. However, many marketers can’t give an empirical reason for their redesign. They know their current website is “underperforming,” and that’s about it. Without clearly and empirically determining how and why your website is underperforming, a redesign is little more than a really expensive and stressful shot in the dark.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWebsite Redesign\n

\n

About Siteimprove

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Suite: The only web governance software that helps you better manage and maintain your website through quality assurance, accessibility, web analytics, SEO, and response – all in one tool.

Web Governance Essentials.

Check out our go-to resources for tips, tricks, web governance best practices and actionable advice to take your website to the next level. Enjoy!

    Live Webinars

    \n
      \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n\n
      \n
      \n

      50 Shades of Gray. Is it accessible or not?

      \n

      Wednesday, January 28,2015 at 1pm CDT 

      \n

      Everyone has their own guide to help them determine levels of disability. What does this tell us? That it’s pretty challenging to determine or define a disability. What does this have to do with web accessibility? When it comes to the WCAG 2.0 Guidelines, pretty much everything.

      \n

      In January’s webinar, we’re going to take a look at why it’s so difficult to meet WCAG accessibility guidelines. There are certain guidelines that are pass/fail—black and white. But so many of the guidelines require a judgment call—gray areas. After all, they are called guidelines, aren’t they?

      \nLearn More & Register \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n\n
      \n
      \n

      Crying Wolf – The Section 508 Refresh

      \n

      Wednesday, March 25,2015 at 1pm CDT 

      \n

      Your accessibility consultant has been warning you for months – even years. Just wait; it’s coming. Is this a case of crying wolf, or will the Section 508 refresh ever happen? Well good people, it’s going to happen eventually, and when it does, will you be ready?

      \n

      In March’s webinar, we’re going to discuss what it will mean for you and your team once the requirements are finally updated. Spoiler alert: you may be more prepared than you think!

      \nLearn More & Register \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n

    On-demand Webinars

    \n
      \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n\n
      \n
      \n

      Including People With Disabilities in Your User Testing

      \n

      We’ve talked in the past about having people with disabilities test your webpages. Many of you are interested in doing this, but have asked, “How do I get started?” It doesn’t need to be a complex process, as there are some great resources available if you know where to look, but there are a few different aspects of the process that you will need to consider.

      \n

      In this on-demand webinar, we provide some ideas on how to implement a plan for including people with disabilities in your user testing.

      \nView Webinar \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n\n
      \n
      \n

      3 Necessary Activities & Skills for Effective Web Analytics

      \n

      It is hard to get an effective web analytics program off the ground, and even harder without a proper understanding of what you need. In this on-demand webinar Steve Hennigs, Vice President of Customer Success at Siteimprove, explores and identifies the three main activities and three required skills your team needs to ensure you move away from just looking at reports and move towards understanding how to improve your website.

      \n

      By the end of this webinar, you will have a better grasp on what you need to invest in and how to allocate your resources to effectively analyze your organization’s digital presence.

      \nView Webinar \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n\n
      \n
      \n

      Web Accessibility Can Boost Your SEO

      \n

      In case having a website that’s accessible to all users wasn’t enough incentive on its own, here’s another reason- it will help boost your SEO rankings. On the surface it may not seem like the two are connected, but behind the subtle scenes of your website’s code, proper accessibility practices are providing a major boost to your SEO.

      \n

      In this on-demand webinar we take a look at not only how web accessibility best practices impact human users and assistive devices, but how it also impacts search engines.

      \nView Webinar \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n\n
      \n
      \n

      Web Accessible Multimedia

      \n

      Making this content more accessible for your users is a simple process, so long as you consider web accessibility guidelines while adding this kind of content to your site.

      \n

      In this on- demand web accessibility webinar, we discuss how to ensure that your multimedia content is web accessible to people with disabilities, by discussing how to meet WCAG guidelines, and then give you a few ways to begin improving your website’s multimedia delivery.

      \nView Now\n
      \n
      \n
      \n

    • \n
      \n
      \n\n
      \n
      \n

      Online Governance For Government

      \n

      Repairing the “rusty bucket”. Online governance for government online.

      \n

      Experience shows that after lots of heady initial enthusiasm and conspicuous spending, many government websites are abandoned and left to suffer a long decline. Thankfully, that is starting to change. A new recognition of the need to spend wisely is creating a more mature approach to Web Governance. The result was a new body with the authority to lead all online development and set the rules by which things must be done. 

      \n

      In this on-demand webinar, we examine how successful this new approach to Web Governance has been and identify some key lessons you can apply to your own operations.

      \nView Webinar \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n\n
      \n
      \n

      The Foundations of a Website Redesign

      \n

      A website redesign isn’t simply a chance to give your website a fresh look. It also gives you an opportunity to reorganize the way your site is structured and how your content is presented in order to support your business objectives. In this 30 minute webinar, we will recap how to prepare for a website redesign, learn how to set the foundation, and frame the website.

      \n

      You’ll walk away from this on-demand webinar with a solid understanding on how to outline and organize your site structure and how to map out primary, secondary, and tertiary content for your website redesign.

      \nView Webinar \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n\n
      \n
      \n

      A Look at Assistive Technology for Web Accessibility

      \n

      Assistive technologies are tools and methods used to make web information available to people with and without disabilities. With the leaps and bounds in technology the last few years, you may not be aware of all of the different kinds of assistive technology that is available.

      \n

      In this webinar, we’ll go beyond the screen reader—we’ll take a look at some different tech that you may not be aware of, or that has made significant changes to the way web pages are interpreted.

      \n

       

      \nView Webinar \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n\n
      \n
      \n

      Cognitive Disabilities & Web Accessibility

      \n

      While sight and hearing disabilities are the most talked-about when it comes to web accessibility, cognitive disabilities actually represent the largest number of computer users with disabilities by a substantial margin.

      \n

      In this webinar, we explain some of the different cognitive disabilities from a web developer’s perspective, and then give you a few tips on how to not only meet WCAG standards, but to improve the experience for ALL your users, including those that may have some form of cognitive disability.

      \nView Webinar\n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n\n
      \n
      \n

      Why Semantic Markup Matters For Web Accessibility

      \n

      HTML was originally designed to deliver documents with a structure that represented the importance and order of information. The creators of HTML were actually scientists who wanted a way to share technical documents. They didn’t really care about the visual look of the document as viewed on a screen—it just needed to correctly convey the information.

      \n

      Semantics and accessibility are a part of HTML by design. Still, they are not useful unless used appropriately. Understanding how to write semantic code properly means knowing how that code works, and how users and machines will read it. 

      \nView Webinar\n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n\n
      \n
      \n

      Web Accessibility & Our Aging Population

      \n

      We’ve mentioned in previous webinars that approximately 20% of our population is living with some form of disability—of varying severity. That statistic, it seems, may be on the rise as medical and technological advances have led to a prolonged life expectancy for a generation that actually remembers what life was like before the Internet. With age comes the potential for impairments or disabilities that make it difficult to manage our day-to-day activities. One of those activities involves our interaction with the Internet and the devices we use to access it. 

      \n

      In this on-demand web accessibility webinar, we talk about the importance of accessible coding practices that affect our older population.

      \nView Webinar \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n\n
      \n
      \n

      Roles & Responsibilities On a Web Team

      \n

      People are the most important part of any system of Web Governance. Yet, roles and responsibilities on many digital teams have not kept pace with changes in online activity. This has often led to dangerous gaps in operations, as well tension among staff over “who does what”.

      In this webinar we’ll explore how to restore ‘industrial peace’ by delivering the clear job descriptions your people need.

      \nView Webinar\n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n\n
      \n
      \n

      Making Data Tables Accessible For Your Website

      \n

      We can all agree that using an HTML table for page layout is wrong. That said, there are some appropriate uses for tables on websites. The problem is now to understand the proper way to make a table accessible.

      \n

      Tables are not to be feared or avoided! With some careful planning and a better understanding of the different table elements and attributes, you too may add usable data tables to your web pages. In this webinar, we’re going to show you how to work with tables on your webpages.

      \nView Webinar \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n\n
      \n
      \n

      Website Content Consistency- Why It’s Important and How to Sustain It

      \n

      Websites have grown in both size and importance to organizations no matter the industry. At the same time peoples’ expectations for a consistent experience are high and regulations on the web are better defined. How can organizations keep up?

      \n

      In this webinar we explore- the challenges organizations face, the impact inconsistent content can have and review steps you can take in order to avoid hurting your credibility and negatively impacting your bottom line.

      \nView Webinar \n
      \n
      \n
      \n

      \n

      Assistive technologies are tools and methods used to make web information available to people with and without disabilities. With the leaps and bounds in technology the last few years, you may not be aware of all of the different kinds of assistive technology that is available.

      \n

      In this webinar, we’ll go beyond the screen reader—we’ll take a look at some different tech that you may not be aware of, or that has made significant changes to the way web pages are interpreted.

      Two Approaches to Better Web Governance in Your University

      \n

      In this 45 min webinar, you’ll learn about a new “Framework of Web Governance”. This framework can improve your online management in 3 crucial ways and is particularly suitable for large, complex organizations like universities.

      \n

      Ultimately, this framework will give you the confidence you need to design a better system of management and lead to enhanced decisions in such critical areas as staffing, technology, budgeting & more.

      Introduction to Web Accessibility

      \n

      Does your website meet web accessibility standards? Do you know the steps to take to start making your website compliant today? Do you know about North America’s different web accessibility standards? If you answered NO to any of the questions above this webinar is a must.

      \n

      This 30 minute recorded webinar will introduce you to web accessibility, and give you action items you can take with you today to start making your website accessible.

      How to Create Accessible PDFs in InDesign

      \n

      Ensuring that the documents available on your website are accessible for everyone is important for every organization. Unfortunately, the process of actually making your documents accessible to everyone isn’t common knowledge. This guide will teach you how to create accessible PDFs using Adobe InDesign.

      \nView Webinar \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n\n
      \n
      \n

      Why Making PDF Accessible Documents is Important

      \n

      Making your PDF documents accessible is important so that all users are able to access your information—no matter its format. Not only is making your content accessible a best practice, some companies are also required to maintain accessibility and follow standards from Section 508 of the Rehabilitation Act as amended in 1998.

      \n

      This 30 minute recorded webinar you will learn: Why and how to define an accessible document, when to use vs. not use PDF files, alternatives for PDF content and where to start when creating PDF documents.

      \nView Webinar\n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n\n
      \n
      \n

      How to Prepare for a Website Redesign

      \n

      Redesigning a website goes much deeper than just the way it looks. Unfortunately, most marketing and web design folks will use this opportunity to focus entirely on the visual design of their website, overlooking the fundamental first step of preparation.

      \n

      This 30-minute recorded webinar will help you plan, prep, and über organize for a successful website redesign before you start your design process.

      Content Governance in 5 Easy Steps

      \n

      Governance of web content can make headaches and anxiety galore for web masters trying to keep the peace. What are some practical and specific tips you can use to keep your team on the same page and calling your institution by the same name?

      \n

      In this 45 min webinar, Ahava Leibtag, author of The Digital Crown: Winning at Content on the Web, walks through 5 steps you can use instead of painkillers to whip your content into a cohesive, consistent and polished winner.

      We get a lot of great questions about how to get the most out of our tools, web governance best practices, creating engaging content, and more.       Website Study: The State of Fortune 1000 Websites

      \n

      Siteimprove used their Web Governance suite to collect information from the websites of 86 companies listed on the S&P Top 100. The results are summarized in this study. The remaining 14 companies were not included in this study as their website contained code that prevented our tool from analyzing their site without permission.

      \n

      This study provides benchmarking for your Fortune 1000’s website quality standards.

      \nDownload\n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n\n
      \n
      \n

      Website Study: The State of Canadian Legal Websites

      \n

      Siteimprove used their Web Governance suite to collect information from the websites of 53 of Canada’s most prominent law firms. The results are summarized in this study. The study has been broken down into 34 Small and Mid-Sized firms, and 29 Large firms.

      \n

      This study provides benchmarking for your legal service’s website quality standards.

      eBook: Web Analytics Where to Begin

      \n

      People love the Internet. A lot. In fact, 92% of online adults rely on search engines when looking for information. Web analytics provide you with a better understanding of how visitors are finding your website, how they interact with it, and how effectively your website is contributing to your business goals.

      \n

      Download this complimentary web analytics eBook and gain a better understanding of what web analytics are and how you can use them to achieve your business goals.

      \nDownload\n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n\n
      \n
      \n

      eBook: The Must-Have Web Accessibility Handbook

      \n

      Web Accessibility is about allowing people with and without disabilities to have access to the information they want and need from your website. With reports of 1 in 5 people claiming some sort of disability, 20% of the population is just too large of a group to ignore.

      \n

      Download this complimentary web accessibility handbook by Siteimprove and learn everything you need to know to make your website accessible.

      \nDownload\n

      \n

      Guide: How to Create Accessible PDFs

      \n

      A Step-by-Step Guide on How to Create Accessible PDFs. Ensuring that the documents available on your website are accessible for everyone is important for every organization. Unfortunately, the process of actually making your documents accessible to everyone isn’t common knowledge. This guide will teach you how to create accessible PDFs using Microsoft Word and Adobe InDesign.

      \nEmail it to me\n
      \n
      \n
      \n

      Guide: Siteimprove During a Website Redesign

      \n

      Siteimprove can help ensure your redesign stays on track. Let’s face it: the majority of website redesign projects are unmitigated disasters, plagued with scope creep, delays, departmental demands, and internal politics. But with proper tools and training, you can significantly lessen the strain of your next redesign.

      \nemail it to me\n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n\n
      \n
      \n

      eBook: Preparing for a Website Redesign

      \n

      Make sure your next website redesign begins on solid footing. Your website is the most important marketing tool you have, and you need it to look its best. This eBook will help you ask the right questions and check your blind spots while preparing for a website redesign.

      \nemail it to me\n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n\n
      \n
      \n

      Guide: 8 Deadly Web Analytics Sins

      \n

      With budgets continuing to tighten, and workloads increasing, web analytics has become a must-have in every professional marketer’s toolbox. However, for many it is still difficult to distinguish between reliable data and valid data. The difference is essentially the way in which the analytics data is set up and subsequently interpreted. These eight sins show how data that looks reliable may not be valid.

      \nemail it to me\n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n\n
      \n
      \n

      Website Study: Law Firms

      \n

      Your website is the prospective client’s first stop when evaluating attorneys, and usability errors like broken links and misspellings destroy credibility. When looking for meticulous and timely legal support, who wouldn’t have a difficult time overlooking a 404 error when signing up for a client alert, or finding the word “Technolgy” under your list of practices? Download this free website study for law firms (AM Law 100 largest websites) and see how your website stacks up.

      \nEmail it to me\n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n\n
      \n
      \n

      Website Study: Local Government

      \n

      When searching for resources like city maps, community calendars, and voting information, broken links prevent them from accessing the content they need, and misspellings prevent them from utilizing your search functions effectively. This study provides benchmarking for local government website quality standards.

      \nEmail it to me\n
      \n
      \n

    Case Studies

    \n
      \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n\n
      \n
      \n

      Case Study: Greater Baltimore Medical Center

      \n

      A brief explanation of how Greater Baltimore Medical Center uses Siteimprove to improve patient education with web governance in their organization.

      \n

      What are some of their website challenges? Ensuring that all of their content is accurate and timely is the biggest challenge.

      \nDownload\n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n\n
      \n
      \n

      Case Study: University of Ontario Institute of Technology

      \n

      A brief explanation of how University of Ontario Institute of Technology uses Siteimprove.

      \n

      What are some of their website challenges? AODA (Accessibility for Ontarians with Disabilities Act) compliance in Ontario is mandatory as per government legislation.  Sites needed to be WCAG Level A compliant by January 1st, 2014, and Siteimprove was the best tool that they found for monitoring multiple sites and alerting their team to where the problems were with actionable reports.

      \nDownload\n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n\n
      \n
      \n

      Case Study: Charles Sturt University

      \n

      This case study gives a brief explanation of how Charles Sturt University, located in Australia, uses Siteimprove to maximise the efficiency of small web teams.

      \n

      What are some of their website challenges? With a very large website and a distributed model of governance, it is very challenging for them to maintain a high-quality user experience and a web presence that is consistently focused on clear business goals.

      \nDownload\n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n\n
      \n
      \n

      Case Study: Deakin University

      \n

      A brief explanation of how Deakin University uses Siteimprove to manage web content between 200+ active content contributors across 4 campuses.

      \n

      What are some of their website challenges? The sheer size of their university and the number of authors make it difficult to monitor every piece of new content.

      \nDownload\n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n\n
      \n
      \n

      Case Study: University of Wollongong

      \n

      A brief explanation of how the University of Wollongong uses Siteimprove to overcome issues commonly faced by university web teams.

      \n

      What are some of their website challenges? User management. The diverse array of people across the site has made it difficult to get coherence, because the people who are assigned the responsibilities may have no experience in website development.

      \nDownload\n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n\n
      \n
      \n

      Case Study: D’Youville College

      \n

      A brief explanation of how D’Youville College uses Siteimprove to overcome issues commonly faced by small college web teams.

      \n

      What are some of their website challenges?  Their largest problem has been one that many other institutions face: Lack of human resources that makes consistent use of any tool for website maintenance challenging. Download now to see how Siteimprove fixed this!

      \nDownload\n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n\n
      \n
      \n

      Case Study: City of St. Louis Park

      \n

      A brief explanation of how the City of St. Louis Park used Siteimprove to overcome issues commonly faced by government web teams.

      \n

      What are some of their website challenges? Managing numerous content contributors, and even though they have a spell checker in their CMS, somehow the errors still get published, and the site ends up with misspellings because of human error.

      \nDownload\n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n

    Product Information

    \n
      \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n\n
      \n
      \n

      Siteimprove Web Governance Suite

      \n

      Maintaining the quality and integrity of your website’s content is a breeze with Siteimprove Web Governance Suite. Save time, money and energy by having your tools in one simple interface.

      \nDownload\n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n\n
      \n
      \n

      Module Overview: Siteimprove Quality Assurance

      \n

      Siteimprove Quality Assurance module provides powerful reporting and project management tools to keep your website running smoothly without overloading your to-do list.

      \nDownload\n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n\n
      \n
      \n

      Module Overview: Siteimprove Accessibility Section 508

      \n

      Siteimprove Web Governance Suite takes the guesswork and confusion out of making your website accessible to users with disabilities with the Accessibility module. With the Accessibility module you won’t just fix accessibility issues, you’ll understand them. This info sheet highlights Siteimprove’s functionality as it relates to U.S.-mandated Web Accessibility Section 508 guidelines. Siteimprove also checks for WCAG 2.0 guidelines (the more stringent standards that Section 508 is based on)

      \nDownload\n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n\n
      \n
      \n

      Module Overview: Siteimprove Accessibility WCAG 2.0

      \n

      Siteimprove Web Governance Suite takes the guesswork and confusion out of making your website accessible to users with disabilities with the Accessibility module. With the Accessibility module you won’t just fix accessibility issues, you’ll understand them. This info sheet highlights Siteimprove Accessibility module’s functionality as it relates to Web Accessibility WCAG 2.0 (the international standard for web accessibility).

      \nDownload\n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n\n
      \n
      \n

      Module Overview: Siteimprove Analytics

      \n

      Siteimprove Web Analytics module is designed for the everyman, not just the guru. The simple, helpful interface makes it so easy to track your website traffic you’ll actually do it.

      \nDownload\n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n\n
      \n
      \n

      Module Overview: Siteimprove SEO

      \n

      Siteimprove SEO’s module helps make every contributor on your web team Search Engine Optimization (SEO) savvy with this brief overview of features and benefits.

      \nDownload\n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n\n
      \n
      \n

      Module Overview: Siteimprove Response

      \n

      Enjoy peace of mind knowing that your website’s up time and response time are constantly monitored, with SMS and email alerts ensuring you’re the first to know if anything goes wrong with Siteimprove Response module.

      \nDownload\n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n\n
      \n
      \n

      The Importance of Web Governance for Financial Institutions

      \n

      Every year, more customers are converting to online banking. In 2013, 74% of all US households reported paying their bills online*. Broken links to online applications, banking logins, and bill pay options present frustrating roadblocks.

      \n

      With the help of an integrated web governance tool, you can identify concerns with your website’s quality assurance, web accessibility, SEO, analytics, and performance in order to protect your brand standards and reputation.

      \nDownload\n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n\n
      \n

      Siteimprove provides a hosted software suite designed for the marketing professional to save time and assist in improving your overall web presence. This document highlights the primary benefits of each module.

\n\n
\n
\n
\n

As smartphone sales continue to overtake the trusty old PC and mobile internet usage grows now is the time to get serious about your mobile platform. With these five simple steps below you’ll quickly be on your way to creating or improving your mobile user experience.

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792113047:\n\n\n\n\n\nWeb Content, Your Audience, and Search Engines\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Blog

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\nWeb Content, Your Audience, and Search Engines\n

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n10/28/14 10:03 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

Quality over quantity, right? “But wait”, you say. “I thought that adding more content and blogs would help boost my site’s SEO rankings?” Well, yes and no. Simply cramming your website full of unfocused, aimless ramblings is actually a sure fire way to earn the ire of both your readers and that company whose name rhymes with “Moogle”. It’s Google. I’m talking about Google.

\n\n

Unfortunately, when it comes to web content, Google sets the objective standards for what qualifies as “high quality”. Once upon a time, SEO rankings were determined by easily exploitable metrics tied to keywords and page links, which led to far too many websites gaming the system by overloading pages with irrelevant keywords and misleading links in order to get more traffic and higher rankings. The problem here is that these webpages didn’t provide the information that they claimed, resulting in a bad experience for users and prompting Google to set their sights on punishing these types of sites.

\n

While elements like keywords and page links are still hugely important to your SEO rankings, and towards convincing readers that your website will provide them with what they’re looking for, the way in which Google analyzes and aggregates content is constantly evolving.

\n

What should your focus be?

\n

So, more content or more relevant content? Ideally you would be aiming for both, but your focus should be on putting out high-quality content that resonates with your audience.

\n

Some of you may have heard the term “click bait”. This refers to websites and online articles that attempt to get the most traffic to the page as possible, with little regard for how relevant or useful the information will be to readers. These flash-in-the-pan approaches will only hurt websites in the long run as they lead to high bounce rates and low engagement, which is a huge red flag to the search engine gods.

\n

High SEO rankings are not built overnight. They’re built over time by creating a constant and consistent flow of relevant, high quality content.

\n

Standing out from the crowd

\n

While playing by the rules is important, it’s only half the battle. If your content isn’t unique or offering readers something new and different, what incentive do they have to read it?

\n

Chew on this: 41% of consumers would end a brand relationship because of irrelevant content and promotions. If you’re flooding your readers with junk content, or the same nearly-plagiarized content as someone else, all you’re doing is giving them a reason to actively ignore you. You would be better suited not saying anything, than saying something just for the sake of saying something.

\n

At least twice a month, I receive snail mail from a well-known mortgage lender informing me that I could reduce my mortgage payment by up to $1,000 per year. Sounds like a super sweet deal, but I rent an apartment, so the content is all but wasted on me. In the event that I do purchase a home, the chances of me working with that particular company are highly unlikely because they’ve already lost my attention.

\n

Making real connections

\n

Consumers aren’t stupid. After decades of being exposed to every kind of marketing, advertising, and sales pitch known to man, they’ve learned to separate disingenuous schemes from authentic communication.

\n

You need to show your audience that you want to connect with them on a personal level by creating content that they feel will address their individual needs.

\n

Geoffrey James of Inc. Magazine describes the three levels of empathy that can help you connect with your audience.

\n

On-demand empathy

\n

This is the ability to sense what customers want. At a basic level, you understand your audience and what it is they’re looking for.

\n

Solution empathy

\n

This means going beyond understanding a customer's problem and figuring out how to address it. A potential customer usually has a problem that they know they need addressed. Your content at this level needs to directly address that problem and provide the solution to it.

\n

Transcendent empathy

\n

Perhaps the most powerful form of empathy, this means you’re able to create solutions for problems before customers even know that they have it. This is the true heart of real innovation and where you can create the most relevance to distance you from your competitors.

\n

The takeaway here should be this: when it comes to your web content, either tell the same story better, or tell a different story altogether. This might seem like common sense, but far too many organizations simply look at what works for others and then try to copy them. Don’t be afraid to do something different, it just might get you noticed.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

Do a Winter Checkup on Your Internal Search

\n

\nPosted by\nBarbara Hammer-Aebi\n

\n

\n12/27/12 2:43 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

With holidays and winter weather approaching, it’s time to make sure that your internal search engine is ready for specific winter topics.

\n
\n
\n

Winter search topics

\n

You might think that "Christmas" and "snow" are the typical topics to optimize for, and it does make sense to make sure that the most relevant pages of your website come up at the top of your searches for these terms. However, the search terms that are being searched for most often during the holiday season are related to opening hours.

\n

In most organizations, opening hours change during holidays, and we typically see a spike in searches for hours of operation during December and January. Users also search for information about services that may have a change in schedule, like garbage collection.

\n

Preparing for search term synonyms

\n

Forgetting to optimize for synonyms of relevant words is a common mistake. Make sure that you catch all versions of the search terms being used. If you're working to optimize searches for garbage collection, appropriate synonyms of 'garbage' might include:

\n
    \n
  • Trash
    • \n
  • Refuse
    • \n
  • Waste
    • \n
  • Bin
    • \n
  • Recycling
    • \n
  • Collection
    • \n
\n

Additionally, opening hours during the holiday period should be searchable for all offices in your organization. If your organization provides services such as a library or a swimming pool then make sure that opening hours for these amenities during the holiday period are searchable too.

\n

Recycle search term statistics from last winter

\n

If you're looking to find specific search terms to optimize your internal search for, I recommend checking your analytics from last year. By looking at which search terms were searched for in December/January last year, you'll get a good idea for where to start this year.

\n

Share your experiences with us!

\n

Do you check and update your internal search?  We'd love to hear your experiences in the comments below. 

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nEnterprise Search\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Get a head start by quality assuring your development site

\n

\nPosted by\nCamilla Simonsen\n

\n

\n12/19/12 2:49 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Many of our customers launched new websites in 2012, and took advantage of running our Quality Assurance and Accessibility checks on the development website. Finding and fixing errors on their website prior to launching is helpful in it's own right, but allowing the web developers early access to the tools has proven to be invaluable.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

The Web Designer's Guide on How to Create Accessible GUIs

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n12/12/12 2:58 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n

    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

As a web designer, several accessibility criteria are especially important to help you ensure as many users as possible can use your web application.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n

How to figure out which How-To’s to write

\n

\nPosted by\nBo Vejgaard\n

\n

\n3/17/13 3:01 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

How-To’s are great. They provide answers to your customers’ questions, but they're also a great opportunity to get some relevant targeted content on your website and boost your SEO efforts. But how do you know which How-To’s to write?

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO\n

\n
\n

Applying Web Governance

\n

\nPosted by\nBo Vejgaard\n

\n

\n1/23/13 2:51 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

It may be one thing to write blog posts about Web Governance, but using it in your day-to-day work is a completely different ball game. In this blog post I’ll show how we’ve tried to apply Web Governance at Siteimprove, and hopefully you’ll learn from our challenges.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Web Governance Policies and Procedures

\n

\nPosted by\nBo Vejgaard\n

Roles and responsibilities in Web Governance

\n

\nPosted by\nBo Vejgaard\n

\n

\n10/10/12 3:59 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Do all employees in your organization know what their role is, and what is expected of them? Do employees know who to ask questions outside their own work area? Do you know what every employee in your web team does?

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n

Going for gold; developing an elite website

\n

\nPosted by\nBo Vejgaard\n

\n

\n9/26/12 4:08 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Like an athlete at the Olympics, your website should be fit and free from injury. This way you can achieve the best performance and value from your website every day.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nAccessibility,\nEnterprise Search,\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Lend the Search Engines a helping hand

\n

\nPosted by\nBo Vejgaard\n

\n

\n8/15/12 4:45 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n

If Google or other search engines can’t read the content on your website, they won't show your pages in the search results.

\n
\n

When you've taken the time to produce content for your website, you probably want it to be found and read by your target audience. Since the vast majority of users use search engines when surfing the web, it's a good idea to help the search engines in easily reading your content. Therefore, it's essential that your website is 'search engine friendly' in the sense that you should make technical and structural enhancements to your website to make it easier for search engines to read.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Map your current web governance

\n

\nPosted by\nBo Vejgaard\n

\n

\n5/30/12 10:57 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Many organizations talk about Web Governance, but what is it – and why should you care? Simply put, Web Governance is a general term for the system of policies and guidelines you use for making decisions about your organization’s web presence. This system may be ill-defined and poorly organized, but it’s important to realize that you already have Web Governance. Thus, it makes sense to start working with Web Governance by mapping your organization’s current state of Web Governance.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Show me the money!

\n

\nPosted by\nBo Vejgaard\n

\n

\n5/16/12 11:08 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

For most e-commerce websites it is relatively straight forward to put a monetary value on visitors, and therefore, it makes sense to put an effort into search engine optimization (SEO) to get more visitors. If you are running an information only website it might be a lot harder to find out how much a visit is worth.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

What is Web Governance?

\n

\nPosted by\nBo Vejgaard\n

\n

\n3/28/12 11:42 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Make your web presence an asset

\n
\n

Web governance is about ensuring full control over the organization's web presence by means of well thought out clear decision-making structures. For some, the organization's web presence is at best a necessary expense, and at worst a risk of legal actions, hacker attacks or the unwanted release of sensitive information. With sensible web governance you can turn the organization's web presence into a valuable asset.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n

\nTell users about your cookies\n

\n

\nPosted by\nMie Elmkvist Jensen\n

\n

\n5/23/12 11:04 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Online privacy is a global hot-button, with lawmakers pressuring organizations to more tightly regulate the information they gather from visitors. The European Union recently enacted legislation dubbed the "cookie directive" has organizations scrambling to make their websites compliant. Many organizations in the US may not realize that they need to comply with these rules if they intend to operate a website in the EU. For those of you who don't run multiple sites, these simple tips may give you a head start preparing for future US legislation.

\n
\n\n
\n

Maybe it's time for a spring cleaning?

\n

Criticism of the new EU cookie directive has been extensive and we have yet to see any brilliant solutions proposed. However, it seems that these rules will not go away, so why not be a little creative and take the opportunity to get some spring cleaning done on your websites?  In May 2011, an EU directive about cookies came into effect and is currently being implemented in the different member countries.  There has been some debate and confusion about how to comply with the rules. Even though this is a European directive, all websites doing business in Europe should comply, and it might be useful for your users at the same time.

One purpose of the rules is to increase self-regulation in this area, which means that it is up to each website to form their own solution ensuring compliance. Therefore, it is surprising that we are yet to see good examples of solutions in a world where these kinds of cases are instantly turned into a business case.

\n

What should I do?

\n

There are 4 main points that you should be aware of in terms of complying with the regulations. The rules apply to all websites.

\n
    \n
  1. Anyone who has a website that uses cookies should inform their visitors thereof.
    2. \n
  2. Information must be easily accessible and clear, using language that the end user will understand so that every user will be adequately informed.
    3. \n
  3. The user should be informed about the purpose of the website's cookies and who stores their data.
    4. \n
  4. Lastly, it is also the website owner's responsibility to obtain consent from the user. This aspect is crucial when wanting to comply with the regulation.
    5. \n
\n


You should be aware that the consent of the user must be obtained before any cookies are set. You must therefore ensure that no cookies are set at the moment when a user enters your website, but only after the user has accepted cookies. You should be able to control when cookies are set, however this might seem incomprehensible to many. The reason many people might find it difficult to meet this demand, is that they do not know exactly which cookies are set by their website. Maybe that's exactly why an audit and perhaps a spring cleaning are needed.

\n

Why should I do it?

\n

The quick answer is; 'because the regulation says so,' but let's have a look at the purpose of the rules: Those visiting your website are informed about what happens. Additionally, visitors must have the option to opt out. When you put it this way, it's probably only a few who will oppose to the idea, because who doesn't support having the freedom to choose?

However, there are still some who may ignore the rule, because they fear that many will opt out, which will make their web analytics less exact. They believe that many will opt out "because they do not know what it is." Paradoxically, this answer brings us back to a part of the background for the rules, namely that information about cookies is needed. This will also help to demystify what cookies are not.

A small survey carried out by 40 people via SurveyMonkey indicates that the users who opt out are also those who do not know what a cookie is; thus indicating those who are afraid of what effect the use of cookies has.

First and foremost, it turns out that more than 1 in 3 people do not know what cookies are, despite the fact that 90% of them use the Internet on a daily basis for several purposes. At the same time an equal number of respondents said that they feel monitored and are afraid that the cookies were used for the purpose of raising prices. With this in mind one can easily argue that if the website owner has a legal and beneficial purpose with cookies, namely to make the user experience better, it's a good idea to share that message!

\n

How can I use it?

\n

Since the rules came into effect, they have been met with some dissatisfaction. Many believe that it is a measure potentially impairing their web analytics. This is one way of looking at things, but looking at it from a different point of view one might realize the possibilities.

\n

Since a large part of using cookies is to gather knowledge, which ultimately makes the website a better place for the user, there appears to be no reason not to tell the user about it.

\n

Cookies seen through branding glasses

\n

Of course there are website owners who use this technology for bad purposes, but if you don't, there is probably nothing to fear. Maybe it's a bit far-fetched, but looking at this through branding glasses, it is only a good thing that the web team will actually take the time to see how they can make the user experience better. So why not tell the users that their visit is making the web team wiser and the website better?

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792145817:\n\n\n\n\n\nWhat is Web Governance?\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Blog

\n

\n
\n
\n

\nWhat is Web Governance?\n

\n

\nPosted by\nBo Vejgaard\n

\n

\n3/28/12 11:42 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Make your web presence an asset

\n
\n

Web governance is about ensuring full control over the organization's web presence by means of well thought out clear decision-making structures. For some, the organization's web presence is at best a necessary expense, and at worst a risk of legal actions, hacker attacks or the unwanted release of sensitive information. With sensible web governance you can turn the organization's web presence into a valuable asset.

\n\n

Make your Web Governance explicit!

\n

All organizations have web governance, as it is fundamentally about who has the final decision in relation to different aspects of the organization's web activities. In many organizations, responsibility for these activities is not clearly defined or expressed in writing. Who makes decisions and who should be responsible for different areas? This is called "implicit web governance," which means that decisions are made ??based on assumptions and gut feelings without clear management support.

\n

It's important that your organization make its web governance explicitly known, because awareness of responsibility and decision-making authority helps to unify efforts, which may contribute to management support.

\n

More about Web Governance

\n

If you want to learn more about web governance, WelchmanPierpoint's blog is a good place to start. They're experts in the web governance field.

\n

You can also keep an eye on our blog, where we will show you how you can map your current web governance with a web governance framework as a first step.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792149787:\n\n\n\n\n\nDive into search statistics\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n

\nDive into search statistics\n

\n

\nPosted by\nBarbara Hammer-Aebi\n

\n

\n6/6/12 10:54 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Search statistics are not only essential for evaluating and maintaining the search function on your website, they are also useful for many other purposes. It is a free opportunity to learn about what your users expect from your website. Do you have the information users need? Is it well organized, and is it easy to click though to the pages that are most sought after?

\n
\n\n
\n

Direct input from your users

\n

When users submit a search term, they are fundamentally telling you that they have a specific information need which they expect to be answered by your website. Search terms are a direct and clear indication that information on a topic needs to be on your website and it needs to be easy to navigate to. In other words: taking a look at your search statistics helps you improve the user experience on your website based on data!

\n

Get inspiration - compare search statistics to your front page.

\n

By comparing the most frequently searched search terms to the terms on your front page you can get inspiration for both content and layout.

\n

If a term is sought after by many users, the information is not accessible enough. There might be no link at all to the information on the front page, or it might be hidden behind a term that users don't associate with their information need.   Some users might not be able to find the library page if it is only accessible under a link with the text "Leisure."  Check whether a link to information that is in your top search results is properly linked to, with a link that is clearly visible under the scroll-line or in a banner.

\n

To summarize: your search statistics often contain words that are not found via links from the front page or the top navigation. It might indicate that your information architecture is not answering user needs well enough.

\n

Dive deeper - do you have the content that users expect to find?

\n

Is there content on your website about the topics that users searched most for?

\n

Three good statistics that you can use to find the items you need to add content addressing are:

\n
    \n
  1. Search terms with no result.
    2. \n
  2. Searches where users moved on to page two of their result list.
    3. \n
  3. Searches where users left the site after seeing the search result.
    4. \n
\n

If possible, also check the search terms that have been searched for more than five times and identify categories of searches that did not give satisfying results. Categories might be searches for employee names, abbreviations and technical terms.

\n

Once you have determined the topics where the users expect information that is not on your website, decide whether you want to integrate website content about these topics, or whether you want to set up a page that explains that the information is out of the scope of the site with a link to the authoritative source for the topic. For example, there may be many searches for employees in your organization, so you might want to improve the information offered to the employees in your organization.

\n

If there are many searches for content that are located in separate searches, such as employee data, consider integrating the information in the general search. Alternatively, include a reference to the right place to search for personal data.

\n

Search statistics also provide insight into the language people use to find what they are looking for. Do they use abbreviations, outdated words or specific technical terms? Consider replicating your user's choice of wording in the text on your website, or make sure that the internal search finds relevant results, by applying various synonyms to key words.

\n

If you want to get more specific tips for working with search statistics, I recommend the book "Search Statistics for Your Site" by Louis Rosenfeld. It is an easy read and gives hands-on advice for working with search statistics. You can also keep an eye on the blog here, where I will continue to write about internal search and search statistics. 

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

\n

\n Awards\n

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n6/13/12 10:50 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

It's official: we're fun.

\n
\n\n
\n

It's always nice to hear that your coworkers enjoy working with you. A pat on the back or an 'attaboy for a job well done always goes a long way.  But if an 'attaboy makes us proud, having the colleagues' love published in a magazine makes our hearts swell.

\n

We're proud to announce that Siteimprove has been named one of the "Best 100 Companies to Work For" by Minnesota Business Magazine! The decision was based on an employee satisfaction survey, which MN Business Mag explains in their announcement blog post:

\n

"Beginning on February 15, 2012, independent research group, Gilmore Research, gathered information from employee satisfaction surveys over phone and mail. More than 5,700 individuals responded on behalf of hundreds of companies, and the winners were determined by employee scores."

\n

If you're looking for us in the list, we're under the "Small Companies" category :)

\n

We're especially proud of this award because it means the hard work we put into making the office fun and productive has been paying off.

\n

Our company culture

\n

 

\n

No performance review scores were harmed in the making of this photo

\n

 

\n

At Siteimprove, we're people first. We're holistically invested in each other because life outside of work is important, too.

\n

We value pride, passion and thoroughness, and strive to incorporate those core values into everything that we do. We're also an environmentally conscious corporation and a good neighbor to our communities, because sooner or later what goes around comes around.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

\n

\nThe Cost of Your Website's Broken Links\n

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n5/29/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

It may not seem like much on the surface, but deep down, a broken link is doing some serious damage to your website, your reputation, and your business. A single broken link can impact your search engine rankings, your site’s user experience, result in lost customers and revenue, or everyone’s favorite- all of the above.

\n\n

Web users are a fickle bunch. When a website works perfectly, nobody bats an eye because “it’s supposed to be that way”, but when something goes wrong- out come the claws! Don’t get mauled by website errors that are easy to find and easy to fix.

\n

What Causes Broken Links?

\n

Broken links are the ones that bring you to a page that says “404 error” and are often accompanied by a clever comment about how the hamster is out to lunch, or blaming it on the intern. The most common, self-inflicted, causes of broken links are:

\n
    \n
  • Renaming or moving a webpage and forgetting to change your internal links
    • \n
  • Linking to content (PDFs, videos, etc.) that has been moved or deleted
    • \n
  • Linking to a third party page, and not knowing when they change the URL or move the page
    • \n
\n

Whatever the cause, and despite the clever “our bad” message, broken links are frustrating errors that need to be addressed immediately. Let’s take a look at some of the ways in which a broken link can impact your site.

\n

SEO

\n

We recently talked about how the evolving SEO landscape is impacting your website, but the debate over exactly how broken links impact your SEO is ongoing. The almighty Google has stated that simply having a broken link or two on your site won’t hurt your rankings, but the impact shows in other ways.

\n

Broken links stop search engine crawlers in their tracks.

\n

Crawlers are busy little guys (they’ve only got an entire Internet to scan over and over again), so when they run into a broken link, they stop crawling that page and move on to the next one, meaning any pages it hasn’t crawled won’t be indexed or receive a ranking.

\n

Broken links lead to lower website traffic.

\n

If a user encounters a broken link, they will likely be discouraged from continuing to any other pages. By spending less time on your site, search engine algorithms will assume it's because your site isn’t providing visitors with quality content or information, resulting in a lower ranking.

\n

USER EXPERIENCE

\n

We’ve all run into a broken link at some point, and it’s a frustrating experience. Whether it’s preventing us from paying a bill or from watching a video of a baby panda watching a cat video, it’s something we’ll remember the next time we visit that site. That is, if we ever come back.

\n

Users favor sites that work.

\n

No surprise there. If your site is a chaotic mess of broken links that impede users from completing a task, they’ll move on to the site that works- probably one of your competitors. Trust takes time to build, but only a moment to lose.

\n

LOST REVENUE

\n

Broken links are roadblocks in the conversion process. No matter how much time and energy (and money) you’ve spent getting customers to your site, if they can’t reach the point of conversion, all of your efforts will have been wasted.

\n

Good news travels fast. Bad news travels faster

\n

Losing customers is a bummer. Not only are you losing revenue from them, but you’re going to lose their closest friends as well. True story. KISSmetrics did the math, and 44% of users will tell others about a bad online experience.

\n

 

\n

Don’t let broken links derail your online reputation or your business goals. Let us help you find and fix potential website dead ends.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
