\n

\nWhat We Learned At Confab Central 2014\n

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n5/22/14 9:30 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

What is Confab? It’s a 3-day conference aimed at sharing knowledge among professionals who understand the value of creating awesome content. People with backgrounds in Marketing, Design, User Experience, I.T., and Business all come together and challenge one another to think about things in new ways, approach problems with new tactics, and share their successes and #EpicFails in equal measure.

\n

We went as knowledge sponges. Here’s some of the stuff we soaked up.

\n\n

Content & Accessibility

\n

Derek Featherstone’s presentation, “Make Your Content Accessible”, provided practical advice and examples from real projects that looked into web accessibility requirements for content.

\n

Although he didn’t go into detail about WCAG 2.0 and Section 508 accessibility standards in the framework he provided, the takeaways he gave could get any web manager heading in the right direction. Derek discussed the importance of H1/H2/H3 headings, content consistency, and why web managers tend to front load content. Curiosity won’t kill the cat with Derek, who is a leader in Web Accessibility standards and practices. Follow him on twitter, sign up for his newsletter, and check out his website, because this guy knows what he's talking about. The downside is that you have to be willing to pay for the heavy hitting information...

\n

Our suggestion/shameless plug? Check out Kevin Rydberg’s Introduction to Web Accessibility webinar to get a lot of the same great information. Wink wink, nudge nudge.

\n

Analytics

\n

If you want to know what your customers and fans are REALLY saying, look at your analytics data. The data tells a story and, if you’re paying attention, it’s likely to be a bestseller for you and your team.

\n

Mike Powers, Dir. of Electronic Communications at Indiana University of Pennsylvania (no affiliation to the state of Indiana), gave a great presentation on using analytics to improve your website’s content.

\n

You can churn out content all day long, but if no one is looking for it, or looking at it, it’s not helping you achieve your business goals. Data is great for identifying patterns and trends, but it can’t tell you what to do. It’s up to you to listen and recognize what content is working, what content isn’t working, and what content you’re missing.

\n

SEO

\n

James Gunter, Head of Content at TruHearing, gave one of the most informative and entertaining, presentations of this year’s Confab with his insights on Google’s Hummingbird Algorithm. Find out everything we learned here.

\n

Search engine algorithms are getting smarter (duh!); Google in particular. Until recently, cramming your webpages with keywords and outbound links was enough to trick them into thinking that your website was relevant to the search terms. As more and more people began to “game” the system, Google got wise and decided to change the game.

\n

With their Hummingbird update (released in Sept 2013), Google made a definitive statement about what they want to be. They no longer want to provide search results evenly across companies and industries. Google wants to be an information broker. They want to provide users with the best quality content; content that is relevant to the search and is most likely to satisfy the user’s needs.

\n

What Google wants now is high quality content. Feed Google what it wants, or they will eat you instead. It’s that simple. If you’re creating content that people need and are actively trying to find, regardless of whether you were the original creator or not, you’ll be rewarded.

\n

 

\n

The good folks at Confab are filled with useful info, so check out their blog!

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n

\n

\n5 Reasons You Should Care About Website Errors You're Not Responsible For\n

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n12/10/13 9:42 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

If an issue on your organization’s website doesn't fall under your area of responsibility, then it’s not your problem, right? Not so fast. Being part of a successful web team means ensuring the entire site is cohesive and error free. That means setting aside the mindset of “not my area, not my fault” and working with your teammates. Because guess what? A problem you pretend not to notice might just land in your lap later on. Here’s why you should care about mistakes in someone else’s jurisdiction. 

\n
\n
\n

1. Performance

\n

Mistakes can damage a website’s overall performance, and at the end of the day, this shapes your performance too. Broken links, spelling errors, discrepancies, slow response times, etc. can affect your site’s rankings, traffic and credibility. This reflects poorly on the entire team, not just one person. Not to mention if the site is slow or goes down, your work might get put on hold. Paying attention to minor issues and troubleshooting before they escalate saves you time, frustration and a dose of aspirin.

\n

2. It Makes You Look Bad

\n

Your own reputation is on the line when it comes to the website you help produce. For instance, say your business cards state you're an Online Specialist at ABC Company and the homepage header is misspelled. Directing visitors to a site with errors doesn’t win you any credibility points for web professional of the year.

\n

3. Helping Coworkers Will Earn You Friends

\n

Managing a large website is an all-hands-on-deck affair. If you pitch in and help your coworkers, chances are they’ll return the favor. You might even foster a sense of camaraderie. Don’t let your teammate launch that new section with a broken navigation link. Instead, help make it a success. Who knows, you might get a thank you and a colleague who has your back when you need it.

\n

4. You Might Have to Fix It Anyway

\n

Say everyone else is out on vacation and you get an urgent call from the CEO that the election results (the ones that were just announced via an all-member email) are not displaying correctly. Whether it’s your area or not, you’ve just become accountable for the solution. And it needs to be fixed right now. It would’ve been less stressful if you had noticed the glitch before the CEO did.

\n

5. Holes in Jurisdiction

\n

Some issues might not fall under anyone’s specific area of responsibility. Often this can mean content updates are overlooked and errors might go unnoticed. For example, a membership number still reflects the count from three years ago or a calendar widget has no events listed for the entire year. Addressing these issues makes for a more reliable site, and in turn, makes you and your team more successful.

\n

Want to know more about creating smooth-running web content? Check out Hilary Marsh's post on how to assess your content needs or see how Siteimprove can automate error discovery on your website.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

Recent Posts

Do a Winter Checkup on Your Internal Search

\n

\nPosted by\nBarbara Hammer-Aebi\n

\n

\n12/27/12 2:43 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

With holidays and winter weather approaching, it’s time to make sure that your internal search engine is ready for specific winter topics.

\n
\n
\n

Winter search topics

\n

You might think that "Christmas" and "snow" are the typical topics to optimize for, and it does make sense to make sure that the most relevant pages of your website come up at the top of your searches for these terms. However, the search terms that are being searched for most often during the holiday season are related to opening hours.

\n

In most organizations, opening hours change during holidays, and we typically see a spike in searches for hours of operation during December and January. Users also search for information about services that may have a change in schedule, like garbage collection.

\n

Preparing for search term synonyms

\n

Forgetting to optimize for synonyms of relevant words is a common mistake. Make sure that you catch all versions of the search terms being used. If you're working to optimize searches for garbage collection, appropriate synonyms of 'garbage' might include:

\n
    \n
  • Trash
    • \n
  • Refuse
    • \n
  • Waste
    • \n
  • Bin
    • \n
  • Recycling
    • \n
  • Collection
    • \n
\n

Additionally, opening hours during the holiday period should be searchable for all offices in your organization. If your organization provides services such as a library or a swimming pool then make sure that opening hours for these amenities during the holiday period are searchable too.

\n

Recycle search term statistics from last winter

\n

If you're looking to find specific search terms to optimize your internal search for, I recommend checking your analytics from last year. By looking at which search terms were searched for in December/January last year, you'll get a good idea for where to start this year.

\n

Share your experiences with us!

\n

Do you check and update your internal search?  We'd love to hear your experiences in the comments below. 

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nEnterprise Search\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Use Web Governance to Secure a Strong Foundation for Your Search

\n

\nPosted by\nBarbara Hammer-Aebi\n

\n

\n11/28/12 3:08 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Who is in control of your internal search? If you want your search to work well you should include it in your web governance.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

Search Solutions for Mobile Websites

\n

\nPosted by\nBarbara Hammer-Aebi\n

\n

\n10/24/12 3:42 PM\n

\n

    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Are you planning to launch a mobile version of your website? Here are a few ideas for the design of the search function for the mobile site.

\n
\n

Carefully Selected Content: Website Redesign Tips From a Search Perspective

\n

\nPosted by\nBarbara Hammer-Aebi\n

\n

\n10/3/12 4:05 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

The Siteimprove series on maximizing the potential of a website redesign continues with today's post on the internal search function. We'll take a look at ideas on how your internal search can be used as a helping tool in the general design and testing of your website, as well as guidance on how to best design your search page.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nEnterprise Search\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Create an annual search cycle

\n

\nPosted by\nBarbara Hammer-Aebi\n

\n

\n8/22/12 4:41 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Create an annual search cycle to stay one step ahead of your users

\n
\n

If your website has an internal search bar, it's a good idea to always be working on your internal search statistics. If you want to stay a step ahead of your users, you can create an annual cycle detailing search queries by month.  Then you can track and measure which areas need to be prioritized and given more effort.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nEnterprise Search\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Dive into search statistics

\n

\nPosted by\nBarbara Hammer-Aebi\n

\n

\n6/6/12 10:54 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Search statistics are not only essential for evaluating and maintaining the search function on your website, they are also useful for many other purposes. It is a free opportunity to learn about what your users expect from your website. Do you have the information users need? Is it well organized, and is it easy to click though to the pages that are most sought after?

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nEnterprise Search\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

3 Things you can do to improve your internal search

\n

\nPosted by\nBarbara Hammer-Aebi\n

\n

\n4/11/12 11:34 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

You may think you don’t need to do that? After all, you can find content without doing so. It is essential that you use the internal search regularly. Your search page transforms and looks different depending on which search term you use. Users on your website might view a search result page that you have never seen yourself.

\n
\n

Your search function might be in perfect shape, and not need any adjustments at all. If not, it is time to take control of your internal search function. Since the search function uses the content of the pages on your site the process mostly starts with improving the most important pages.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nEnterprise Search\n

\n
\n
\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792132877:\n\n\n\n\n\n4 Tips For A Fall Website Cleanup\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n
\n

\n4 Tips For A Fall Website Cleanup\n

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n10/7/14 10:02 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

Clutter is OK on your desk. Sure, your co-workers will be silently (or not so silently) judging you as stacks of paper, coffee cups, and assorted knick-knacks pile up around your keyboard like garbage in a landfill, but it’s part of your process, right?

\n

Your website, on the other hand, is no place for clutter. Customers expect simple navigation, easy to find information, and useful content. If your website took the summer off to relax, it’s time to put it back to work.

\n

\n

Let’s look at some of the ways you can get your website back into shape.

\n

Clean up broken links & misspellings

\n

The problem:

\n

The reasoning behind this should be pretty obvious, but for far too many organizations, broken links and misspellings have a tendency to build up over time like the aforementioned desk clutter. Like the quirky comfort provided by your messy desk, it can be easy to overlook the affect that your messy website has on others because you see it every day. Unfortunately, when customers who aren’t as familiar with the intricacies of your website’s poor grammar and labyrinth of dead links see it for the first time, it can be a major turn off that hurts your organization’s reputation and could result in lost revenue.

\n

The solution:

\n

Take the time to analyze your most important pages- the ones which see the most traffic and/or drive customers through the conversion process. Correcting misspelled words and fixing broken links on these crucial pages will result in quick, large-scale improvements to the user experience of your website.

\n

Set a goal for your team and determine a timeline for when you want to complete it. For some organizations, it may not be possible to scan every webpage and address every error, and that’s OK. The important thing is make a measurable improvement that will benefit both you and your organization.

\n

Optimize your site architecture and navigation

\n

The problem:

\n

This may come as a surprise to some of you, but the content that you think is the most important to your customers may not be what the customers think is the most important for the customer. That can be a hard pill to swallow when you’ve spent what seems like a large portion of your sanity on laying out your website in a way feels logical, or that you think will allow you to reach your business goals.

\n

Unfortunately, that’s not the way it works. In this case, the customer is always right. They’re going to find what they need, with or with your help, so it’s in your best interest to help them.

\n

The solution:

\n

Data doesn’t lie, check your analytics. Your analytics data will show you the journey that every customer is taking and reveal why they’re coming to your website. Use this information to determine what’s working and what’s not working. What pages are receiving higher or lower than expected traffic and engagement? Where are customers entering and leaving your site? What page elements are they clicking on? All of these metrics will help you decide which pages should be moved higher or lower in the pecking order.

\n

By adjusting your website’s layout to reflect your customers’ needs, you enable them to find what they’re looking for with the least amount of resistance, resulting in more engagement and more business for you, and more warm-fuzzy feelings for the customer.

\n

Web content audit

\n

The problem:

\n

I often ignore the advice I’m about to share here, because all of my content is perfect and it never ceases to serve a purpose. OK, I know that’s not true, but it’s how I feel about every piece of content I write. And that’s the problem. Getting attached to your content will only serve to hold you back and prevent you from providing your customers with the information they’re looking for.

\n

The solution:

\n

Take stock of what content you have. Ask yourself what content you need. Decide what content you can do without. Think of it like the content Hunger Games. In the end, only the most useful and resourceful content will prevail.

\n

Your business needs and your customers’ needs will change, so your content should be constantly evolving to reflect those needs. Over time, content will lose its relevancy. It’s up to you to determine if content can be updated or repurposed in order to continue providing value, or if the odds are not in the content’s favor and it’s time for it to be retired. (Side note: I’m currently high-fiving myself for including a catchphrase from a book/movie series that I have never read/seen!)

\n

Plan for the future

\n

Use what you learned to help dictate future content

\n

Your analytics will tell you how customers are finding you and what they’re looking for. Don’t fight it, give them what they want. If you don’t someone else will.

\n

Once you have a better understanding of what your customers’ needs are, take the opportunity to update your site’s SEO strategy. Identify critical keywords for which you want to rank highly in web searches and weave them into your content. Just be wary of keyword stuffing.

\n

Create content around larger organizational initiatives

\n

Combine what you’ve learned from the content audit with your organization’s future goal. What upcoming campaigns/product releases can you tie-in with to provide a boost to your website traffic while helping customers address their needs?

\n

Hopefully these tips will help you get your digital house in order and ready to entertain guests, but if you'd like some additional insights, download our Content Consistency Webinar below.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n

\nIdentifying Key Performance Indicators and Micro Conversions on B2B Websites\n

\n

\nPosted by\nSteve Hennigs\n

\n

\n4/10/14 10:22 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

This past week I had the opportunity to talk to both the Tampa and Orlando City Groups of the Legal Marketing Association (LMA) Southeastern Chapter about getting value from their web analytics. As with any good analytics framework, there are some key things you can do to begin making meaningful changes to your websites based on data.

\n\n
\n

To get started, there are five key things that every web team should do:

\n
    \n
  1. Identify Key Performance Indicators, (KPIs) Micro Conversions (MCs)
    2. \n
  2. Utilize Events in order to track KPIs and MCs
    3. \n
  3. Make Campaign Tracking part of their outbound marketing process
    4. \n
  4. Use Segmentation
    5. \n
  5. Generate reports in which action is recommended based on the data and set goals
    6. \n
\n

Over the next few weeks I would like to dive into each of these topics in a bit more detail in order to provide more practical advice into how to make this work for you. For these posts I will use Business to Business (B2B) law firms as examples, but the concepts apply to all B2B organizations.

\n

Let’s start with the most important of all the steps: identify KPIs, MCs, and setting targets.

\n

KPIs are metrics that help determine how your website is performing toward your organization’s business objectives. This definition, as provided by author, speaker and Google evangelist Avinash Kaushik, hits at the heart of what good web analysts strive for: Finding the little nugget of information in a sea of data to determine whether your website is performing well or dying a slow death. These metrics aren’t always easy to find because they require that you know what you’re looking for ahead of time.

\n

In a perfect world your Marketing Technologist, Marketing Director or even CMO could provide you with all the direction you need – but in the real world they can only help you frame your big question. You need your leadership to answer it:

\n

Why do we have a website, and what do we expect it to do?

\n

The answer to this question is the starting point you need to ultimately determine what metrics in your analytics tool deserve to be singled out as KPIs. Then you can devote the majority of your attention to these numbers month after month.

\n

You may get answers like “We have a website to showcase our branding,” or “Our website serves as a tool for prospective clients to validate our attorneys.” While these answers both seem vague and unmeasurable, they’re enough to get you started. If you get an answer like “we need the website to be a lead generation tool” then you really have a head start.

\n

For most B2B firms the validation response is very common, so let’s focus our attention there. Often a prospective client will meet an attorney at some sort of event, check out the website (and the bio of that attorney) for some further information and then either disregard the attorney and firm as an option for future business, or contact the attorney to set up a more formal meeting.

\n

There could be other steps taken before a meeting is suggested (for example, the prospect reaching out to their business acquaintances for further information about the attorney and/or firm) but for simplicity’s sake, let’s assume those are the only steps.

\n

In order to identify the correct KPIs, you need to review what actions on the website correlate with prospects contacting you to schedule meetings. So when leadership said the purpose of the site was “validation of the attorneys,” that ultimately means the purpose is lead generation. Many people would like to take it even further and track whether their website actually closes business, but we need to be realistic.

\n

People hire attorneys based on a good relationship and the feeling that the attorney can help them resolve their issues in the best manner possible. A website can only do so much to facilitate that relationship, and if it helps lead to more face-to-face meetings then the website is doing its job.

\n

Because of this, the data within a web analytics tool can help identify KPIs, but the standard “out of the box” information generally isn’t what you need.  In order to be useful, analytics programs have to be customized to your particular needs.

\n

For example: if you can see that people who click on a vcard are more likely to schedule a meeting, then clicks to a vcard is a KPI. To track the KPI, you need to be able to track clicks to vcards (this is called “Event Tracking,” and we’ll cover that in detail in the next installment) and then also see the identities of the people who clicked. Most analytics tools list organizations that have visited your website, which is a blessing and a curse: In some cases it’s great, and gives accurate information about the particular organizations visiting; and in other cases it’s awful, and all you can see is the Internet Service Provider (Comcast, for example).

\n

Once you can see all the relevant organizations who have clicked on vcards within a given time period, you can determine how many of those the firm has been able to do business with in the same time period. That gives you the correlation you are looking for. If you want to test whether this is a good KPI, then do the same exercise with other interactions on your website (clicks to pdfs, clicks to email attorneys, clicks to videos, etc.) and determine which interaction correlates with the most meetings.

\n

This is an example of tying an action taken on your website back to an actual business objective (more meetings with prospective clients for attorneys). At the very least, it gives you some information you can take to the Managing Partner in order to help you collaborate with them to determine what other metrics could be KPIs. Once these are established it goes a long way to you being able to recommend what initiatives to undertake in order to increase your website conversions (visitors who act on your KPIs).

\n

In order to keep your reporting manageable, keep the number of KPIs low. I would suggest a maximum of 4 KPIs. In order to help you trim your list down Avinash states that the traits of a good KPI are as follows:

\n
    \n
  • It’s simple
    • \n
  • It’s relevant
    • \n
  • It’s timely
    • \n
  • It’s instantly useful
    • \n
\n

If a metric is missing even one of these criteria it’s not a good KPI – it’s a “Micro Conversion.”

\n

It would be great if all your visitors took action on one of your KPIs, but that’s just not the way the real world works. In fact, according to a study done by Marketing Sherpa in 2012, only an average of 10% of visitors on a professional services website will convert. So what are the other 90% of your visitors doing??

\n

\n

This is why you also need to identify Micro Conversions (MCs) on your site, actions that are valuable but not valuable enough to be KPIs. If you went through the exercise mentioned above to identify your KPIs, then there should be some metrics that didn’t make the cut. These will be your MCs going forward, and knowing these numbers will help you recommend what changes to make in your digital processes to help move people through the funnel and either take action on a KPI or convert offline (schedule a meeting).

\n

I understand that this is a lot of information and work, but if you really want to understand the value of your website and make consistent improvement, it is work that must be done.

\n

These are also moving targets, as there will be different initiatives throughout the year geared towards developing additional business. When those come up, you should evaluate your KPIs and MCs to ensure they’re still viable. Analyzing your website is not something you do just once – it’s an ongoing process.

\n

This is the first step towards analytics nirvana. In the next installment, we’ll look at how Event Tracking helps make this happen.

\n

In the meantime, check out this website benchmarking report on the Top 100 US Law Firms:

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n

\nMake Campaign Tracking Part of Your Website Measuring Process\n

\n

\nPosted by\nSteve Hennigs\n

\n

\n4/22/14 12:07 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

In order to fully understand the success of your digital marketing efforts you need the complete picture. In this post we will review a key component to capturing information you may be missing, how to implement that process in your organization and provide some guidance on how to add some serious value when you are armed with a more complete data set.

\n\n

(This is the third installment in our series on web analytics for B2B websites. If you’re just joining us, we began by reviewing the importance of Identifying KPIs and MCs for your site, and then tracking those interactions with Events)

\n

Understand Your Website Traffic

\n

Once you have started collecting data on your desired outcomes for the website (KPIs and MCs) you are still missing an important piece of the puzzle: a complete picture of your Acquisition Strategy, or in layman’s terms, “how people are getting to your website.”

\n

Most web analytics tools provide a very basic overview of how people are coming to your website, which probably looks something like this:

\n

\n

The three standard metrics included out of the box are usually Direct Traffic, traffic from Referral Websites, and traffic from Search Engines. Understanding them is important, but they make up only half of what you’ll need to fully measure the success of your website and other digital efforts.

\n

The missing sources are Email Marketing, Social Media, and Offline Marketing (e.g. a print ad directing people to your website). Once you add data from these sources to the standard three, you will have a complete picture of how people are getting to your site - and more importantly, you’ll have the ability to determine which channels are delivering towards your desired outcomes!

\n

Use Campaign Tracking Parameters

\n

So, how do you get data from the three missing sources into your web analytics tool? By adding extra text to your links when sharing them online. This text doesn’t do anything differently when people view the page, but it appears in your analytics tool and can be used to match shared links with campaigns. This extra text is called “campaign tracking parameters.”

\n

While you may not have heard of campaign tracking parameters before, you’ve probably seen them. Parameters appear in a URL after a question mark (?) and are separated by an ampersand (&).  [Fun fact: you can add a question mark to a URL and then write anything you want; as long as there are no spaces it will work normally. Go ahead and try it on this page!]

\n

Let’s take a look at what a URL with campaign tracking parameters looks like in the real world. How many parameters do you see in this URL, and what are they?

\n

http://siteimprove.com/?utm_source=SiteimproveUS&utm_medium=Websitelink&utm_campaign=Mailsignatur

\n

There are three parameters in this URL:

\n
    \n
  1. utm_source
    2. \n
  2. utm_medium
    3. \n
  3. utm_campaign
    4. \n
\n

Here's the same URL again, with the parameters bolded:

\n

http://siteimprove.com/?utm_source=SiteimproveUS&utm_medium=Websitelink&utm_campaign=Mailsignatur

\n

What makes these parameters valuable to your analytics efforts is how they are recognized in your analytics program.

\n

\n

By default Siteimprove Analytics identifies five parameters as Campaign; utm_campaign, utm_medium, utm_source, utm_content and utm_term. So as a Siteimprove customer you can use them without having to do any setup.

\n

Combining Traffic Sources with KPIs and MCs

\n

Let’s talk about how you can use your Traffic Sources information combined with your KPI and MC data for really powerful analysis:

\n

When analyzing your data, you may find that visitors are more or less likely to do certain things depending on which traffic source they came from.

\n

For instance, let’s say you want people to fill out a signup form for your newsletter, and the form appears on several different pages. This form is a KPI for your organization because people who subscribe to this particular newsletter are more likely to contact you for a quote, request a demo, set up a meeting, etc. One of your goals over the next quarter is to increase subscriptions to the newsletter by 10% over the previous quarter. Your plan to do so is by promoting the newsletter in the following ways:

\n
    \n
  1. Adding a link to the subscribe page in your staffs’ email signatures
    2. \n
  2. Sending an email campaign with the subscribe page as the call-to-action
    3. \n
  3. Promoting the newsletter via LinkedIn and Twitter
    4. \n
  4. Featuring the newsletter more prominently on your homepage
    5. \n
\n

For the first three promotion methods above, you’ll want to use Campaign Tracking. (Assuming you’ve already identified your KPIs and are tracking them via Event Tracking, as outlined in our first two blog posts of this series)

\n

In order to get value out of campaign tracking, you need to:

\n
    \n
  1. Understand how many newsletter subscribers were added in the past quarter
    2. \n
  2. Identify and gain approval on the naming conventions you will use for the signature link, email campaign link and social media links
    3. \n
  3. Educate anyone who will be sending out a link to the Subscribe page on how to add Campaign Tracking Parameters to that link
    4. \n
  4. Check in pretty routinely early in the quarter to ensure that the process is being followed and then as needed until quarter’s end
    5. \n
\n

Evaluate Your Performance

\n

The end of the quarter is when the real fun begins. Then you can review whether or not you hit your goal of increasing subscriptions by 10%. In this example, let’s say that you did achieve that goal. This is ultimately the number that leadership will want to see, but you can’t stop there. As a web analyst, it’s your job to provide additional understanding as to why you were able to do so. Part of that analysis will be reviewing which promotional method drove the most subscribers.

\n

This is the part where you’ll be happy you went through the work of making Campaign Tracking part of your process. You’ll be able look back at the past three months and have definitive evidence as to which method was the most successful, and which may have been a waste of time. In addition to making you look like a genius in front of your boss, this knowledge can be used to help determine future investments (time, people and money).

\n

In order to truly provide value from your analytics data, there are still a few steps before you’re done. You still need to add context to your data and report that information forward in a way that leadership can easily understand.

\n

Incidentally, adding context to your data is the focus of our next installment in this series. Stay tuned!

\n


You can get a full explanation of Campaign Tracking Parameters, their situational use and some quick tips by downloading this educational document, "Campaign Tracking in Siteimprove Analytics."

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n

\n New website – Think web accessibility from day 1\n

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n8/29/12 4:40 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

If you are about to redesign your website, now is a good time to focus on getting a website that can be used by as many people as possible. Here are some tips on when and how to make requirements and focus on accessibility throughout the process.

\n
\n\n
\n

Requirements Specification

\n

When you are writing your accessibility requirement specifications your web development team, it is important that you use the right standards. (The best standards are the international guidelines for accessibility outlined by WCAG) In web design projects, it's fairly common for the buyer to request that the website be designed in conformance with WCAG 2.0 on level AA, however this requirement may not be as straightforward as it would appear at first glance.  In the middle of the project, how will you determine whether or not the website meets your expectations? My recommendation is that you explicitly state the individual success criteria which you wish to have compliance with. Have your website developer state if and how this is going to be complied with. Define the following (in a table or similar):

\n
    \n
  • Reference to criteria:  1.1.1
    • \n
  • Description of criteria: Non-text Content: All non-text content that is…
    • \n
  • Notes on criteria: This is relevant for images, …
    • \n
  • Developer's field for description of solution: (leave blank for developer to fill out)
    • \n
\n

Do the same for all the criteria. You can also state, if a criteria is an ultimate requirement or a desirable requirement.

\n

It's also important that the CMS used to build the website helps web editors publish accessible content. Make requirements on how this should be ensured. You can pick the necessary check points from the guidelines on accessible authoring tools ATAG (these guidelines dictate that the tool generates accessible web content, helps web editors to publish accessible content, and that the tool itself is accessible). In my experience, you'll want to explicitly state requirements for how to:

\n
    \n
  • Handle alternative texts for images
    • \n
  • The use of headings
    • \n
  • The ability to create accessible data tables
    • \n
  • How to make quotes (< q > and < blockquote >)
    • \n
  • How to enter page titles
    • \n
  • How the  html code created by the CMS complies with the W3C standards
    • \n
  • How to tag change of language in the text entered
    • \n
\n

Consider also the organization's design manual and if there are any contradictions with the accessibility guidelines. For example there are specific accessibility guidelines on the contrast ratio between background and text colors. For this reason it is important to use 'accessible' color combinations.

\n

Design and Development

\n

A handful of the accessibility criteria are relevant when starting the phase of designing and doing wire frames. Think about navigation, the use of headings, colors, link texts and descriptions where the user is to click on, fill out or choose content on web pages.

\n

When it comes to the process of development most of the accessibility criteria are relevant. Therefore it is important that the people developing the solution have a solid understanding of accessibility. Make sure you test the solution during the process from start to finish. Do not wait until the acceptance test. By then it's nearly impossible task to correct possible errors and shortcomings before the site goes live. It's especially important that the templates for different pages are tested as early as possible before building on them, to avoid spreading mistakes to hundreds or thousands of pages.

\n

Publishing content

\n

Make sure you train web editors on how to publish content the 'accessible way'. This way, when content is added both in the development phase and after you've launched, it furthers your site's accessibility rather than introducing new accessibility issues.

\n

Media players, forms, and old content

\n

Areas often being neglected are where 3rd party solutions are integrated, such as media players and forms. Remember these in the process. They should also be accessible!

\n

Also think about content being migrated from the old system into the new. If you change the html/xhtml version the syntax specifications from W3C are different. There might also be content from the old system that is not accessible. After all your hard work, the last thing you want is to carry old problems over to your new website.

\n

Besides accessibility there are many other considerations to include when launching a new website. Download our complimentary eBook.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792147167:\n\n\n\n\n\nPutting a Face on Accessibility Part II\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n

\nPutting a Face on Accessibility Part II\n

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n7/1/13 10:21 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Professor Chris Olson has had a really busy year. Chris recently bought and moved into a house. Like many home purchases, there was a bit of remodeling that took place before the move to make the space more usable. Chris will be sharing that new home with his fiancé Cindy. Chris and Cindy were engaged on New Year’s Eve. Chris has been teaching graduate and undergraduate level computer and web programming classes for the past seven years. In March 2013, he successfully defended his doctoral dissertation, “Awareness of Accessibility in Computer-based Instructional Materials and Faculty Demographics in South Dakota Public Universities.”

\n
\n
\n

Chris is quadriplegic—paralyzed from the shoulders down. In 2001, he was in a car accident and shattered his c5 vertebrae. While he has limited use of his bicep muscles, he has no movement or sensations in his hands.

\n

Typically the first thing many of us think of when we hear web accessibility is the need to use a screen reader. A screen reader is not the only kind of assistive technology used. Chris relies on typing sticks to operate his various computer input devices, and also relies on Dragon Naturally Speaking for dictation. He does not use a computer mouse; instead, he relies on keyboard navigation.

\n

Some additional assistive technologies Chris relies on include Windows mouse keys, and Windows speech recognition. In addition, Chris uses a Samsung Galaxy smartphone, a Kindle reader, and is looking into a Nest Learning Thermostat for his house, which he can control from his smart phone.

\n

Too often, we forget to put a face on people with disabilities, instead lumping them into categories:

\n
    \n
  • Blindness or Low Vision
    • \n
  • Deaf/Hard-of-Hearing
    • \n
  • Learning Disabilities
    • \n
  • Medical Disabilities
    • \n
  • Physical Disabilities
    • \n
\n

As web developers, here are a few additional methods that will assist your users that utilize non-mouse assistive technologies.

\n

Tab order

\n

Tabbing navigation is the ability for a user to navigate between focusable elements with the tab key of the computer keyboard. Usually, pressing [Tab] will move focus to the next element, such as hyperlinks or form fields. The order of focusing can be controlled by using "tabindex."

\n

According to the W3C, the “tabindex” attribute is "the position of the current element in the tabbing order for the current document." "Tabindex" works sequentially, tabindex="1," tabindex="2," etc. Elements with no tabindex set will appear after, in the order they appear on the page.

\n

Labels on form elements

\n

The label tag is a HTML forms tag that allows developers to tell the browser or user-agent that text appearing on the page is actually a label for a form element. The label tag says, "This content is describing a form element and should be associated with it." The label tag also provides a larger clickable area for items like radio buttons. You can click on the text that the label tag encloses as well as the radio button itself.

\n

Adequate clickable space on a link

\n

Make links, buttons and checkboxes easily clickable. A label on form elements, as we just talked about, is an example of increasing the clickable area. Linking block elements, instead of individual text, is another great way to increase the clickable area. You may choose to increase the padding of an element with CSS to make the clickable area larger.

\n

Visible keyboard focus

\n

Visible keyboard focus is a critical factor in ensuring access for sighted users who rely on a keyboard for navigating the Web. Unfortunately, design aesthetic has outweighed this important practice. CSS reset files are notorious for removing this visual element. Remember that focus is listed in WCAG 2.0 as success criterion 2.4.7 for a reason. Work with your designer to create some form of visual identifier for focus - you don't have to rely on the "ugly dotted border."

\n

For more information about creating accessible websites, read our blog posts “Web Editors: Create Accessible Websites”, “Web Developers: Create an Accessible Website”, and The Web Designer's Guide on How to Create Accessible GUIs. This is the second post in the series “Putting A Face on Accessibility.” We are focusing on individual people with disabilities in this series, both getting to know that person and how they use web technology. Our first story featured Keith Bundy.

\n

When you sit in on one of Dr. Olson’s programming classes, prepare to be inspired by his coding prowess, as well as his typing speed—30 words-per-minute. Chris will continue to amaze as you observe his influence on the next generation of professional web developers.

\n
\n
\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792155057:\n\n\n\n\n\nFour good ideas on how to find the right keywords\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n

\nFour good ideas on how to find the right keywords\n

\n

\nPosted by\nThea Straub\n

\n

\n6/20/12 10:48 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Keywords are at the very heart of search engine optimization and finding the right keywords can make or break your SEO success. It is therefore very important to find the right keywords to target. It is impossible to optimize your website for all interesting keywords, so you will want to start out with the most important ones. Here, we will give you four good ideas on how to find the right keywords.

\n
\n\n
\n

1) Put yourself in your visitor's shoes. Think about words and phrases that your target group of users would use in a search. Keep in mind that the regular visitor will not necessarily use the same jargon you do. So ask someone who does not work in your field which keywords they would use to search for your products or services in search engines.

\n


2) Make use of available statistics. You will find statistics for internal searches on your website in our web tool 'Analytics' under Internal Search. This list is very informative because the statistics give you the facts and not assumptions about what keywords your visitors are searching for. But remember that your internal search is limited to your website, which means it is often enough with a stand-alone keyword. In Google, a stand-alone keyword will often be too generic, causing searchers to make their search more specific using a keyword phrase of 2-4 words to get a relevant result.

\n

In the SEO module under Performance, you will find statistics on keywords from external search engines (such as Google). These statistics will tell you what keywords your visitors are using to find you in the search engines, but keep in mind that these statistics only include keywords your website already ranks well for and where your visitors have clicked your link in the search results. We cannot show statistics for searches where users have searched for your products or services and your link was not clicked or was not included in search results at all.

\n


3) Find popular keywords with 'Google Suggest.' When you start entering a keyword in Google, their autocomplete feature offers suggestions for popular keywords; try to play with this feature and see what keywords are typically used.

\n

 

\n

 

\n

4) Use Google's own keyword tool. Google has created a free tool with the purpose of selling more ads. However, the tool can also be used for purposes other than creating ads. You submit a few keyword ideas, and the tool suggests a lot of related keywords. You will have to sort through the resulting keywords with a firm hand as a lot of the suggestions will not be relevant. Take a look at the numbers in the column to the right (local searches) and find the popular keywords that are  relevant to your website.

Make a long list of all the keywords and phrases you can think of. Be creative and think about synonyms as well as descriptive terms. When you can't think of anything else, you need to start editing and prioritizing until you have a manageable list. Enjoy!

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

Topics:\nSEO\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792160327:\n\n\n\n\n\nAre You Coding Your Website Data Tables For Accessibility?\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n

\nAre You Coding Your Website Data Tables For Accessibility?\n

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n5/13/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

We can all agree that using an HTML table for page layout is wrong. For those of you who didn’t know that, thank you for sticking with me into sentence two, I promise this will all make sense if you keep reading. There are many appropriate uses for tables on websites, but the problem lies in understanding the proper way to make those tables accessible for all users. Don’t panic, tables are not to be feared or avoided! With some careful planning and a better understanding of the different table elements and attributes, you too can add usable data tables to your web pages.

\n\n

If you’re already feeling a little overwhelmed, don’t worry, I’ll be discussing more specific examples for working with tables on your webpages in my free on-demand webinar, which you can download at the end of this blog.

\n

Layout Tables vs. Data Tables

\n

Tables have been used for page layout since the early days of the Web. Due to advancements in both W3C recommendations and coding capabilities, table layouts are becoming another distant memory, as they may cause considerable accessibility problems. The presentation and layout of web page elements can and should be controlled through appropriate cascading style sheets (CSS) and tables should be used to display data only.

\n

Use the Simplest Table Possible

\n

Simple Tables

\n

A simple table basically means that there is only one header row and one header column in the table. A header specifies the type of information in the row/column. There are no merged cells within a simple table. Once we have merged cells, we need to approach the table as a complex table, which have different coding considerations. It may even be preferable to create more than one simple table instead of using a complex table.

\n

Complex Tables

\n

Sometimes, complex tables are required. Some data tables may require more than one level of row and/or column heading. Most people will not find this a problem; visually the table is logical. However, Assistive Technology, like screen readers, will need very specific instructions to correlate these extra levels of headings to the information contained in the data cells.

\n

Marking Up Tables

\n

The very first step toward creating an accessible data table is to define row and column headers. This is easy enough to do. In the markup, the <td> tag is used for table data cells and the <th> tag is used for table header cells.

\n

Simply changing the appropriate <td> tags to <th> tags signifies that the information within the cell is different from the information that still sits in a <td> cell. The location of the cell does not change. Now before you say, “That was easy,” be aware that this is just the first part of making that simple table accessible. It gets a little more complicated, but not too complicated. I promise.

\n

Associate Data Cells with Appropriate Headers

\n

Now that we've created headers, we need to associate the cells with the appropriate headers. There are two ways to associate data cells with their headers.

\n

The Scope Attribute

\n

The scope attribute tells the browser and screen reader that everything under the column is related to the header at the top, and everything to the right of the row header is related to that header. By specifying the “col” or “row” attribute in addition to the scope attribute, you’ve tied that column or row to the correct header. A screen reader now has the instructions it needs to present the table correctly.

\n

Headers and ID Attributes

\n

Another way to accomplish this is to use the headers and ID attributes.

\n

This method is NOT recommended for simple tables, but may be useful in complex tables. The headers and ID method should only be used when there is more than one logical level in a table, and when it is necessary to link more than two headers with a data cell. Stick with the scope attribute unless your table is more complex and the scope attribute will not do the trick.

\n

Proportional Sizing

\n

Use proportional table sizing rather than absolute or fixed-pixel sizing. Let the browser window determine the width of the table whenever possible. By establishing a fixed width on a table, you are not allowing the table to flow into the viewport area available. Luckily, this is becoming a more standard practice now that we are planning and implementing responsive website layouts.

\n

Other Table Markups

\n

<caption> Tags

\n

Tables should have some sort of identifying title or caption to them. Using the <caption> tag can do this, and you can add the <caption> tag right after the opening <table> tag. It is not absolutely necessary to have <caption> tags on every data table for the sake of accessibility, but it is still a good practice. And of course all of these additional attributes and tags can be styled appropriately with your cascading style sheets.

\n

Summary Attribute

\n

The summary attribute is not a requirement for simple tables, but can increase the comprehension of more complex tables for people using screen readers. A good summary can highlight the important elements of a table, and help the user to know what data can be found in the table. A good practice is to only use table summaries when they do what they were designed to do: summarize complex data.

\n

Want to learn more about Accessible Tables?

\n

There are other more complex methods of marking up tables than those discussed here. Please download the on-demand webinar below for a more hands-on explanation of coding tables. The webinar will be a useful guide to understanding some of the different techniques for making tables accessible. I’ll show code examples and discuss:

\n
    \n
  • Simple tables
    • \n
  • Complex tables
    • \n
  • The correct attributes to make a table accessible
    • \n
  • Proportional Sizing
    • \n
  • Additional Table code attributes
    • \n
\n

 

\n

\n \n \n  

\n

 

\n
\n

The 'Governance' Component of Content Strategy Success

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n5/14/13 3:58 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

According to Google CEO, Eric Schmidt, every two days now we create as much content as we did from the dawn of civilization up until 2003. While this mind numbing figure may scare off those considering how to govern content, the last installment in our content strategy series will show how with a clear plan, and the assistance of some clever tools, navigating this mammoth task doesn't need to take you a millennium.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

The 'Publication' Component of Content Strategy Success

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n4/22/13 4:04 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Having your content published was once difficult, yet with the emergence of the new media age entry requirements have almost all but disappeared. Instead, the internet has made it possible for almost everyone to share their content, but this isn’t without risks.

\n
\n
\n

With the increasing digitization of the business world, it has now become essential for organizations to become publishers in order to compete against competitors, and gain attention from their target audiences. Yet haphazard publishing can be dangerous for an organization's reputation, especially if standards of reliability, accountability, accuracy and trust slip.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

The 'Creation' Component of Content Strategy Success

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n4/16/13 4:09 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Previously we introduced the concept of ‘content strategy,’ and explained the three essential components that constitute its lifecycle – creation, publication, and governance. In this blog, will delve deeper into how Siteimprove can assist you during the first component: ‘creation.’

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

The three components of Content Strategy success

\n

\nPosted by\nJack Oldham\n

\n

\n4/8/13 2:48 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Creating effective website content can be an arduous task, especially when so many factors must be considered: varying role capacities, internal politics, customer expectations etc. However, following a structured strategy can make creating focused content a piece of cake!

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Ensuring the last laugh isn't at your expense

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n2/6/13 4:16 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

We all enjoy having a good laugh at spelling mistakes, but the real challenge for those responsible for websites is ensuring that the last laugh isn’t at your expense.

\n
\n
\n

Maintaining your website's credibility is not easy, especially given that for most of us checking spelling mistakes, grammatical errors, and broken links is hardly our must-have hobby for 2013, however if you wish to ensure your website's success it is essential.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Applying Web Governance

\n

\nPosted by\nBo Vejgaard\n

\n

\n1/23/13 2:51 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

It may be one thing to write blog posts about Web Governance, but using it in your day-to-day work is a completely different ball game. In this blog post I’ll show how we’ve tried to apply Web Governance at Siteimprove, and hopefully you’ll learn from our challenges.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Web Governance Policies and Procedures

\n

\nPosted by\nBo Vejgaard\n

\n

\n12/5/12 3:05 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n

  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Where would an employee go with questions to how a specific task is done on your website?

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Use Web Governance to Secure a Strong Foundation for Your Search

\n

\nPosted by\nBarbara Hammer-Aebi\n

\n

\n11/28/12 3:08 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Who is in control of your internal search? If you want your search to work well you should include it in your web governance.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n

Web Analytics & Web Governance

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n11/14/12 3:28 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

As defined in our previous blog post on Web Governance, among other things, about clarifying and distribute ownership and responsibility of the tasks involved in an organization's web presence. This applies of course also when it comes to web analytics, which in 2012 should be a fully integrated part of all organizations overall web strategy.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

The Dollars and Cents of Web Governance

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n11/6/12 11:51 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

One of the biggest reasons we hear people say they don’t have a solid web governance strategy is because they lack the time and money required to implement it. What they often don’t realize is that time and money are exactly what a web governance strategy saves. In this post, we’ll be presenting a few examples from several other industries who have already spent the time and money to discover the savings offered by web governance.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

How to figure out which How-To’s to write

\n

\nPosted by\nBo Vejgaard\n

\n

\n3/17/13 3:01 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

How-To’s are great. They provide answers to your customers’ questions, but they're also a great opportunity to get some relevant targeted content on your website and boost your SEO efforts. But how do you know which How-To’s to write?

\n
\nRead More\n

\n

Simple, yet lethal SEO no-no's

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n2/19/13 3:07 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

“A website is like an island resort. It serves no purpose if no one can find it” Dr. Clinton Cimring, Trademarker of the acronym S.E.O

\n
\n
\n

While most of us focus a lot of our time and money on improving our SEO, it's often the basics that are our undoing. With that in mind, we've come up with a list of common elementary mistakes that people make time and time again. And remember if your SEO efforts still aren't paying off then it may be time to consider investing in an SEO tool that helps take the mystery out of it.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Ensuring the last laugh isn't at your expense

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n2/6/13 4:16 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

We all enjoy having a good laugh at spelling mistakes, but the real challenge for those responsible for websites is ensuring that the last laugh isn’t at your expense.

\n
\n
\n

Maintaining your website's credibility is not easy, especially given that for most of us checking spelling mistakes, grammatical errors, and broken links is hardly our must-have hobby for 2013, however if you wish to ensure your website's success it is essential.

\n
\nRead More\n

Web Editors: Create Accessible Websites

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n1/29/13 9:38 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

As a web editor you are responsible for the content you publish on the website and it’s accessibility. Do you know how to support accessibility when you write texts and add images and links on a web page?

\n
\n
\n

This is the final blog post in a series of 3 that cover websites and accessibility with a role-based approach. This post is meant for web editors. The previous was intended for web designers and for web developers. I will give concrete tips on how to create an accessible web site.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n

It may be one thing to write blog posts about Web Governance, but using it in your day-to-day work is a completely different ball game. In this blog post I’ll show how we’ve tried to apply Web Governance at Siteimprove, and hopefully you’ll learn from our challenges.

Top 5 SEO and Accessibility Overlaps

\n

    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Did you know that guidelines and best practices for SEO and web accessibility have many overlaps, and that with a little consideration you can kill two birds with one stone? We give you our top five areas that make your website more searchable and at the same time accessible for more users.

\n

Web Developers: Create an Accessible Website

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n1/2/13 2:35 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Are you developing your website for many types of users, or are you primarily developing for people who access websites in much the same way as you do? Do you know how dyslexic users, people who are colorblind, people with impairments and others navigate the web?

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Do a Winter Checkup on Your Internal Search

\n

\nPosted by\nBarbara Hammer-Aebi\n

\n

\n12/27/12 2:43 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

With holidays and winter weather approaching, it’s time to make sure that your internal search engine is ready for specific winter topics.

\n
\n
\n

Winter search topics

\n

You might think that "Christmas" and "snow" are the typical topics to optimize for, and it does make sense to make sure that the most relevant pages of your website come up at the top of your searches for these terms. However, the search terms that are being searched for most often during the holiday season are related to opening hours.

\n

In most organizations, opening hours change during holidays, and we typically see a spike in searches for hours of operation during December and January. Users also search for information about services that may have a change in schedule, like garbage collection.

\n

Preparing for search term synonyms

\n

Forgetting to optimize for synonyms of relevant words is a common mistake. Make sure that you catch all versions of the search terms being used. If you're working to optimize searches for garbage collection, appropriate synonyms of 'garbage' might include:

\n
    \n
  • Trash
    • \n
  • Refuse
    • \n
  • Waste
    • \n
  • Bin
    • \n
  • Recycling
    • \n
  • Collection
    • \n
\n

Additionally, opening hours during the holiday period should be searchable for all offices in your organization. If your organization provides services such as a library or a swimming pool then make sure that opening hours for these amenities during the holiday period are searchable too.

\n

Recycle search term statistics from last winter

\n

If you're looking to find specific search terms to optimize your internal search for, I recommend checking your analytics from last year. By looking at which search terms were searched for in December/January last year, you'll get a good idea for where to start this year.

\n

Share your experiences with us!

\n

Do you check and update your internal search?  We'd love to hear your experiences in the comments below. 

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nEnterprise Search\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Get a head start by quality assuring your development site

\n

\nPosted by\nCamilla Simonsen\n

\n

\n12/19/12 2:49 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Many of our customers launched new websites in 2012, and took advantage of running our Quality Assurance and Accessibility checks on the development website. Finding and fixing errors on their website prior to launching is helpful in it's own right, but allowing the web developers early access to the tools has proven to be invaluable.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Show me the money!

\n

\nPosted by\nBo Vejgaard\n

\n

\n5/16/12 11:08 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

For most e-commerce websites it is relatively straight forward to put a monetary value on visitors, and therefore, it makes sense to put an effort into search engine optimization (SEO) to get more visitors. If you are running an information only website it might be a lot harder to find out how much a visit is worth.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

3 ways to improve your accessibility right now

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n5/9/12 11:11 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

It can be difficult to know where to start if you have not implemented web accessibility before. Where do you begin and how do you finish? Some areas require time and a targeted effort whilst there are some ways in which you can improve your website accessibility right away, and at the same time conform with 3 important criteria in WCAG (Web Content Accessibility Guidelines).

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

The added bonus of ensuring web accessibility

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n5/2/12 11:19 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Are you looking to attract more visitors and retain happier users of your website? If so, then read on! By conforming with a number of accessibility criteria you can not only optimize the accessibility of your website, but also ensure good usability and increased visibility in search engines (SEO).

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n

Corporate Responsibility at Siteimprove

\n

\nPosted by\nCamilla Simonsen\n

\n

\n4/25/12 11:21 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

At Siteimprove we work with Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) as an essential part of the growth we experience in our three main markets in the UK, USA and in Denmark. A lot of initiatives have already been introduced, for instance we work hard to contribute to a higher degree of Web Accessibility on public and private websites. We wish to minimize our carbon footprint and offer our employees a sound and exciting working environment, in order to encourage employees to create new and even better Web Governance solutions for our customers.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nResponsibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Why do I suddenly have more accessibility issues?

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n4/18/12 11:28 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n

Web professionals looking to improve their website accessibility using Siteimprove tools are finding that they have more issues in Quality Assurance, than they had in the former SiteCheck, but they are unsure of why.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

3 Things you can do to improve your internal search

\n

\nPosted by\nBarbara Hammer-Aebi\n

\n

\n4/11/12 11:34 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

You may think you don’t need to do that? After all, you can find content without doing so. It is essential that you use the internal search regularly. Your search page transforms and looks different depending on which search term you use. Users on your website might view a search result page that you have never seen yourself.

\n
\n

Your search function might be in perfect shape, and not need any adjustments at all. If not, it is time to take control of your internal search function. Since the search function uses the content of the pages on your site the process mostly starts with improving the most important pages.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nEnterprise Search\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Why is web analytics important?

\n

\nPosted by\nBarbara Hammer-Aebi\n

\n4/4/12 11:37 AM\n

    \n

\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

What can analytics do for your site performance and business goals?

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

What is Web Governance?

\n

\nPosted by\nBo Vejgaard\n

\n

\n3/28/12 11:42 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Make your web presence an asset

\n
\n

Web governance is about ensuring full control over the organization's web presence by means of well thought out clear decision-making structures. For some, the organization's web presence is at best a necessary expense, and at worst a risk of legal actions, hacker attacks or the unwanted release of sensitive information. With sensible web governance you can turn the organization's web presence into a valuable asset.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

What is Web Accessibility?

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n3/21/12 11:48 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n

The term “Accessibility” is often used broadly, but there is a clear definition of what we mean: ensuring that as many users as possible can navigate and comprehend a website.

\n
\n

Being in the accessibility industry, I meet many web professionals with differing thoughts on what web accessibility is. Some think that it's all about uptime and response time (Availability), others say usability, and some say search engine optimization (SEO) or "find-ability." Some believe that accessibility means that everything on your website can be read aloud in an automated way. I think you get the idea.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Suite: The only web governance software that helps you better manage and maintain your website through quality assurance, accessibility, web analytics, SEO, and response – all in one tool.
